THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John R. Chapman and Cynthia S. Chapman,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Upstate RV & Marine, d/b/a Holiday Kamper & Boats-Piedmont and Tracker Marine, Inc.,       
Defendants,
Of whom Upstate RV & Marine, d/b/a Holiday Kamper & Boats-Piedmont is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3959
Heard November 10, 2004 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald E. Rothwell, of Irmo, for Appellant.
Robert Scott Dover, of Pickens, for Respondents.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  John R. Chapman and his wife, Cynthia S. Chapman, brought this action seeking damages for breach of contract, breach of express and implied warranties, and revocation of acceptance.Â  The Chapmans sought costs and attorneyâ€™s fees under the Magnuson-Moss Act.Â  Upstate RV & Marine, d/b/a Holiday Kamper & Boats-Piedmont (â€œHolidayâ€) appeals from the judgment awarding the Chapmans damages, costs, and attorneyâ€™s fees.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
The Chapmans sought to purchase a thirty-two-foot houseboat of durable quality so that they could spend long weekends with their family camping overnight at the lake.Â  After speaking with a salesman from Holiday and reviewing a pamphlet, they selected a boat manufactured by Tracker Marine, Inc, and purchased it from Holiday for $42,524.Â  The negotiated boat included several features the Chapmans wanted:Â  a rubberized mat on the roof for sunbathing; a cooking area with running water, a stove, grill, and table; a bathroom; sleeping quarters; a generator; a stereo; heating and air conditioning; an upgraded motor; and a three-axle trailer with guide rollers for ease in loading.Â  The Chapmansâ€™ boat was delivered from Columbia to Holiday in Seneca on June 29, 1996.Â  Upon inspection, Mr. Chapman noticed that the trailer did not have guide rollers, the boat was dented on the side, the lettering was coming off, the molding around the generator cover was coming off, the rubber mat on the roof had wood sticking through it, the bathroom door was scratched, the fender on the trailer was split, and the grill cover was cracked.Â Â  
On July 1, 1996, the Chapmans attempted to take the boat to the lake for the first time.Â  They realized the brakes on the trailer did not work properly, so they returned home.Â  After having the brakes repaired, the Chapmans again attempted to use the boat.Â  The Chapmans and their children became stranded on the lake overnight when the generator and battery failed.Â  During that time, the carbon monoxide alarm went off and the children were soaked with rain because the canvas tent over the sleeping quarters leaked.Â  Because the trailer did not have guide rollers, Mr. Chapman had to get into the water behind the boat and maneuver it onto the trailer when they wanted to leave. 
The Chapmans also noticed numerous other defects and examples of poor workmanship.Â  Some of the problems included poor sealing in the engine, a missing trim gauge on the motor, a cracked speaker cover, a leak in the sink, missing snaps on the canvas cover, a screen door which fell off, and a malfunctioning horn.Â  The boat was taken to Holiday for repairs.Â  However, when the Chapmans received the boat a month later in mid-August 1996, many of the problems were not fixed.Â  The Chapmans took the boat out just two times after that.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  closing, the Chapmans had to transport the boat to the Greenville store on January 16, 1997.Â  The Chapmans were told the parts were purchased to make the necessary repairs.Â  They checked on the progress of the boat every month thereafter.Â  On June 19, 1997, the Chapmans were informed they could pick up their boat.Â  When they arrived, a Holiday employee informed them that they had been misled, that the boat had not been repaired, and that the parts to repair the boat had been ordered.Â  
The Chapmans intended to return the boat to Holiday at that time.Â  However, Doris Vaughn, the new service manager for Holiday, persuaded them to allow the boat to be fixed and she would make sure it was done no later than the Chapmansâ€™ next long weekend, which was July 16, 1997.Â  The Chapmans returned the following day to see if work had begun on the repairs.Â  When they arrived a worker was painting the roof where the rubberized mat had previously been.Â  Mr. Chapman refused to accept a painted surface, instead demanding a new mat so the deck could be used as intended.Â  
Unfortunately, when they arrived on July 16, 1997, the boat was not repaired.Â  The horn was disassembled; the molding was not repaired; the rubberized mat on the roof was not replaced; the canvas top was not repaired; the door had not been repaired; and there were no rollers on the trailer for loading the boat.Â  The Chapmans informed Holiday of their intention to revoke acceptance of the boat.Â  
In May 1999, the Chapmans instituted this action for breach of express and implied warranties and for revocation of acceptance.Â  At trial, Mr. and Mrs. Chapman testified regarding the boatâ€™s numerous defects and their attempts to have them fixed.Â  Mr. Chapman testified that the value of the boat without defects was the purchase price, or $42,524, and he would not have paid that price if he had known about the defects.Â  Mrs. Chapman testified the boat was worth no more than $15,000 at the time of revocation in July 1997.Â  She testified at trial that she would not â€œgive $2,000â€ for the boat because of the neglect and damage done since it was returned to Holidayâ€™s possession.Â  
Charles Long, an employee of Tracker, testified regarding the boatâ€™s value.Â  He stated the NADA Guidebookâ€™s low retail value for the boat was $15,300, and the average retail value was $19,850.Â  He testified the trailer separately had a low retail value of $3,450 and an average retail value of $4,015.Â  On cross-examination, Long opined the boat was worth $21,585 given its condition in 2001. 
The jury returned a verdict in favor of the Chapmans on both their breach of warranty and revocation of acceptance claims.Â  The jury found Holiday was the only defendant liable on either claim.Â  On the breach of warranty claim, the jury awarded $22,324.Â  The jury awarded $48,000 on the revocation of acceptance claim.Â  
 Holiday filed post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), new trial absolute, new trial nisi remittitur, and to require the Chapmans to elect their remedy.Â  The Chapmans filed to collect attorneyâ€™s fees under the Magnuson-Moss Act, 15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 2310(d) (1998).Â  The trial judge denied the motions for JNOV and new trial absolute.Â  The judge granted the motion for new trial nisi remittitur as to the revocation of acceptance claim, and reduced the verdict to $45,000.Â  The Chapmanâ€™s were awarded $20,957.69 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs on their breach of warranty claim under the Magnuson-Moss Act and were required to elect between their remedies.Â  
Holiday filed a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP to alter or amend the judgment. Â The motion restated the same arguments made in their previous JNOV and new trial motions.Â  Additionally, Holiday sought to further reduce the award under the revocation of acceptance claim and to reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The motion was denied.Â  The Chapmans elected to recover under their breach of warranty claim.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS


 Holiday contends the trial judge erred in failing to grant its motions for a new trial absolute or, in the alternative, for a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Holiday contends the Chapmans failed to properly prove damages under the breach of warranty claim because they offered no proof of the value of the boat as accepted.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this issue is not preserved.Â  Holiday raised the damages issue in its directed verdict motion; however, the issue was raised in the context of causation.Â  Specifically, Holiday argued that it had done nothing wrong and any damages were due to a defective product manufactured by Tracker Marine, Inc., its co-defendant.Â  In its directed verdict motion, Holiday never questioned the existence of damages nor the measure of damages.Â  Failure to raise the issue that is now on appeal in the directed verdict motion bars review on appeal.Â  See In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 93, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001) (noting that since only issues raised in the directed verdict motion may be raised in the JNOV motion, motions newly raised in the JNOV motion were not preserved for review); Roland v. Palmetto Hills, 308 S.C. 283, 286, 417 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œA motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict is a renewal of the directed verdict motion and cannot raise grounds beyond those raised in the directed verdict.â€).Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  
In any event, even if the issue were preserved, we find Holidayâ€™s appeal to be without merit.Â  â€œThe grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by error of law.â€Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  

The trial judge must grant a new trial absolute if the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive so as to shock the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the figure reached was the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, partiality, corruption or some other improper motives . . . The failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial absolute in this situation amounts to an abuse of discretion and on appeal this Court will grant a new trial absolute.Â  

Vinson, 324 S.C. at 404-05, 477 S.E.2d at 723.Â  â€œAlternatively, the trial court may grant a new trial absolute when, sitting as the thirteenth juror, it concludes the juryâ€™s verdict is not supported by the evidence.â€Â  Duncan v. Hampton Co. Sch. Dist. No. 2, 335 S.C. 535, 547, 517 S.E.2d 449, 455 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, substantial deference should be given to a juryâ€™s determination of damages.Â  Knoke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 324 S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996).Â  
â€œThe trial judge alone has the power to grant a new trial nisi when he finds the amount of the verdict to be merely inadequate or excessive. . . .â€Â  McCourt by & Through McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 308, 457 S.E.2d 603, 607 (1995).Â  Compelling reasons, however, must be given to justify invading the juryâ€™s province in this manner.Â  Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 61, 427 S.E.2d 673, 676 (1993).Â  Whether to deny a motion for a new trial nisi is a matter within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  Vinson, 324 S.C. at 406, 477 S.E.2d at 723-24.
In a breach of warranty action, the measure of damages is â€œthe difference at the time and place of acceptance between the value of the goods accepted and the value they would have had if they had been as warranted, unless special circumstances show proximate damages of a different amount.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-714(2) (2003).Â  The absence of proof of one of these values normally bars recovery and warrants the granting of a new trial.Â  See Ellison v. Heritage Dodge, 283 S.C. 21, 26, 320 S.E.2d 716, 718-19 (Ct. App. 1984) (affirming the trial judgeâ€™s grant of an involuntary nonsuit in a breach of warranty action where the plaintiff failed to prove the fair market value of a van in its defective condition at the time the plaintiff returned the vehicle to the secured creditor).Â  However, our courts have upheld jury verdicts where evidence existed from which the jury could determine the value of the goods in their defective condition.Â  Draffin v. Chrysler Motors Corp, 252 S.C. 348, 351, 166 S.E.2d 305, 307 (1969) (holding that although there was no direct testimony by the plaintiff regarding the value of the automobile in its defective condition, testimony from the plaintiff, his wife, and his son regarding the defects and evidence regarding the resale value of the automobile were sufficient to enable the jury to arrive at the value in its defective condition); Durant v. Palmetto Chevrolet, Inc., 241 S.C. 508, 515, 129 S.E.2d 323, 326 (1963) (holding that evidence of a trade-in value of a defective car, testimony regarding the numerous defects with the car, and evidence regarding numerous attempts to repair the car, were sufficient to support the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of the plaintiff, despite the lack of opinion evidence regarding the carâ€™s value on the date of sale). 
The basis of Holidayâ€™s argument on appeal is that the Chapmans offered insufficient proof of a necessary element of their claimâ€”the value of the boat at the time they received it in the condition it was received.Â  Holiday contends Mrs. Chapmanâ€™s testimony that the boat was only worth $15,000 one year after the date of receipt was insufficient evidence of the value of the boat when it was received; thus, there was no evidence to support the juryâ€™s award.Â  
As in Draffin and Durant, we find the evidence was â€œsufficient to enable the jury to arrive at the fair market valueâ€ of the boat in its defective condition.Â  Ellison, 283 S.C. at 25, 320 S.E.2d at 718.Â  The Chapmans returned the boat to Holiday for repairs from mid-July 1996 to mid-August 1996 and from November or December 1996 until transferring it to the Greenville store in January 1997, where it stayed until the Chapmans revoked acceptance in July 1997.Â  Thus, at most, the boat was in the Chapmansâ€™ possession for only five months, during which time the boat was only used on two occasions.Â  Holiday, by contrast, had possession of the boat approximately eight months prior to revocation.Â  Because the boat was used so infrequently, it was in the Chapmanâ€™s possession for such a short time, and Holiday failed to make the necessary repairs by the time of revocation, the jury could reasonably have concluded that the valuation from the time of revocation would also apply to the value of the boat at the time of acceptance.
Further, the Chapmans testified at length about the numerous problems caused by the defects, including being stranded on the lake with their young children, and about the numerous times they were promised by Holiday that the boat would be repaired.Â  Mrs. Chapman valued the boat at the time they revoked acceptance at $15,000.Â  Trackerâ€™s expert, Long, gave several 2001 NADA values for the boat and trailer combined, ranging from $18,750 to $23,865.Â  Long also testified that it was his opinion that the boat was worth $21,585 in 2001.Â  The jury awarded $22,324 in damages, indicating they believed that was the difference between the value of the boat as warranted and the boat as received in its defective condition.Â  To arrive at that damages figure, the jury had to value the boat in its defective condition at approximately $20,000.Â  The testimony regarding the boatâ€™s value at the time of revocation, the numerous defects, and the failed attempts to get it repaired was evidence from which the jury could determine the value of the boat at the time of acceptance.Â  The juryâ€™s award is clearly within the range of that evidence.Â  
We cannot say the amount awarded shocks the conscience of this court, nor do we find it merely excessive given the facts and circumstances of this case.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Holidayâ€™s motions for a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi remittitur.
CONCLUSION
Evidence was presented at trial from which the jury could determine the value of the boat in its defective condition.Â  Thus, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Holidayâ€™s motions for a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi remittitur as to the damages awarded on the warranty claim.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial judge is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Holiday raised several issues on appeal, arguing the trial court erred in:Â  (1) denying its motion for JNOV because the Chapmans failed to establish liability under warranty, damages caused by Holiday, or the right to revocation; (2) denying its motions for a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi remittitur where there was no evidence of the boatâ€™s value under the breach of warranty claim; (3) denying the motion for a new trial where the admission of a 2001 photograph of the boat was prejudicial; and (4) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees where Holiday is not liable under the Magnuson-Moss warranty act.Â  At oral argument, counsel for Holiday informed the court that Holiday was waiving all issues except the proof of damages on the breach of warranty claim.Â  Accordingly, we address only Holidayâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in denying its motion for a new trial or new trial nisi remittitur in light of the Chapmansâ€™ failure to prove damages.Â Â  
[2]Â  The Chapmans argue that Holidayâ€™s appeal was untimely because the substance of Holidayâ€™s Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion was identical to its prior post-trial motions for a new trial absolute and new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Thus, the Chapmans argue, the Rule 59(e) motion was actually a successive new trial motion and did not toll the time for filing the appeal.Â  However, in deciding the post-trial motions, the trial court for the first time awarded the Chapmans attorneyâ€™s fees under the Magnuson-Moss Act.Â  Although Holidayâ€™s subsequent Rule 59(e) motion did address some issues it raised in its prior motion, it also raised an objection to the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, Holidayâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion was not successive.Â  Holiday timely filed its appeal after the order on the Rule 59(e) motion.Â  See Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR (holding that the notice of appeal from a civil judgment must be served upon all respondents within thirty days after receipt of written notice of entry of judgment, and a timely motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, will toll the time for an appeal until receipt of written notice of entry of order granting or denying the motion); Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 21, 602 S.E.2d 772, 778 (2004) (holding that a party â€œusually is free to file an initial Rule 59(e) motion, regardless of whether the previous JNOV/new trial motions were made orally or in writing, without unnecessary concern the repetition of an issue or argument made in a previous motion will result in a subsequent appeal being dismissed as untimelyâ€).

title: State v. Jones
description: In this criminal matter, Jones appeals his conviction for trafficking in crack cocaine.  He contends the trial judge erred in failing to suppress the drug evidence because it was tainted fruit seized in an illegal detention following a traffic stop.  Specifically, Jones asserts the officer's actions during the traffic stop amounted to an illegal detention exceeding the scope of the traffic stop.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Timothy Jones,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3961
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  Appellant, Timothy Jones, was tried for and convicted of trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  He appeals, asserting the trial judge erred in failing to suppress the drug evidence because it was tainted fruit seized in an illegal detention.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
At the start of the case, Jones made a pretrial motion to suppress the drug evidence in this case arguing it was the result of a prolonged detention that became unlawful.Â  Jones asserted the officer, who pulled Jones over for speeding, exceeded the scope of the stop when he questioned Jones and requested backup for the purpose of searching the vehicle.Â  The court held an in camera hearing, at which time the State presented the testimony of Trooper J. Ryan Elrod.Â  
Trooper Elrod first testified to his normal procedure when pulling a car over for speeding.Â  He stated that he generally calls in the traffic stop to dispatch, approaches the vehicle, speaks to the driver, and then directs the driver to get out of the car and stand at the left front wheel of the patrol car.Â  He then asks â€œwhere theyâ€™re going, if they realize their speed, where theyâ€™re coming from, . . . why theyâ€™re in a hurry, is there any reason for their speed . . . .â€Â  He requests license, registration, and proof of insurance.Â  On average, with no unusual circumstances, the normal traffic stop takes him five to six minutes.Â  
Trooper Elrod testified that, at approximately 1:30 p.m. on September 25, 2001, he was on I-85 in Spartanburg County patrolling northbound traffic for speeding violations when he observed an automobile traveling the interstate at a high rate of speed.Â  His radar indicated the car was traveling 82 miles an hour in the 70 mile an hour zone.Â  Trooper Elrod pulled the car over, walked up to the driverâ€™s side, explained to the driver why he had stopped him, and asked the driver to step back to the patrol vehicle while he issued him a summons for speeding.Â  The driver of the vehicle was Timothy Jones.Â  Trooper Elrod described the weather as mild, breezy, and very cool for that time of year.Â  Jones exited the vehicle and walked back to the trooperâ€™s car as requested.Â  
While in the process of issuing the traffic ticket, Trooper Elrod asked Jones where he and the other occupants of the vehicle were coming from, and Jones indicated they had been in Greenville to visit his cousin regarding opening up a barbershop business.Â  He first told the trooper they had stayed in a hotel, but could not tell him the name or location of the hotel.Â  He then told Trooper Elrod they stayed with his cousin, but he could not give the trooper his cousinâ€™s name or the location of his cousinâ€™s residence. Â 
Jones presented the trooper with a driverâ€™s license, but did not produce registration for the vehicle.Â  Jones appeared very nervous.Â  The driverâ€™s license came back clear, but since Jones did not have his registration, Trooper Elrod returned to the vehicle, looked at the vehicle identification number, and then went over to the passenger to request assistance in locating the registration.Â  After fumbling through some paperwork, the front seat passenger, Mr. Patterson, produced the registration.Â  During this time, Trooper Elrod asked Patterson where they had been.Â  Patterson responded they had been to Spartanburg for the last two days, but he could not remember where in Spartanburg.Â  As Trooper Elrod spoke to Patterson, the back seat passenger, Mr. Clark, stated something to the trooper which could not be heard due to the noise on the interstate.Â  Trooper Elrod shut the front passenger door, opened up the rear door, and asked Clark what he had said.Â  Clark then stated they had been in Atlanta that morning, not Spartanburg.Â  
At that point, Trooper Elrod closed the door to the car and called for any unit in the area to come to his location.Â  His call for backup occurred approximately seven minutes into the stop.Â  Just prior to requesting backup, Trooper Elrod asked Jones if there were any weapons or anything else in the vehicle he needed to know about and Jones answered there were not.Â  The trooper then asked if Jones had any problem with him searching the vehicle and Jones responded he had no problem with that.Â  
It took about three to four minutes for the back-up officer, Trooper Earle, to arrive on the scene.Â  During this time, Trooper Elrod continued to fill out the paperwork on Jonesâ€™ speeding ticket.Â  The trooper was in the process of explaining the ticket to Jones when he observed the front seat passenger, Patterson, jump out of the vehicle with a white towel in his hand.Â  This occurred almost simultaneously with the point at which Trooper Earle arrived on the scene.Â  Trooper Earle began a foot pursuit of Patterson while Trooper Elrod pursued in his car.Â  The officers were able to catch Patterson after he ran into some briars.Â  During the chase, Trooper Elrod observed Patterson throwing objects into the briars.Â  The objects retrieved were bags containing white, powdery substances, which were later determined to be 230.83 grams of crack cocaine.Â  
When asked why he called for back-up, the trooper explained:

I had three different stories on where they had been.Â  I was by myself.Â  The driver of the vehicle, Mr. Jones, was, in my opinion, was very uneasy.Â  He was sweating profusely.Â  Again, it was a cool day.Â  He acted very nervous.Â  And it was one on three, and regardless of the situation, I felt that I needed back-up at the scene, andÂ  - - - I just didnâ€™t feel something was right, and in my safety, I called for back-up.

Trooper Elrod admitted that part of the reason he called for backup was that he would need a secondary officer to search the vehicle, but denied that his purpose in talking with Jones was to wait for backup to arrive.Â  Rather, he stated he was in the process of writing the citation and explaining it to Jones when Patterson jumped from the car and ran.Â  
Jones argued to the trial judge that the officer had gone on a â€œfishing expeditionâ€ and prolonged his detention for the purpose of performing a search.Â  He asserted the questioning of the passengers and the extended conversation the officer had with him about where they had been and what they were doing was merely a â€œruseâ€ so he could eventually search the car.Â  Jones maintained â€œanything this officer did with [him] pursuant to this stop after a reasonable period of time had expired for him to issue him the summons . . . [was] unreasonableâ€ and was therefore an illegal detention.Â  
The trial judge found the amount of time of this traffic stop was not too long and that it was a legal stop and detention.Â  He determined, because Jones did not initially produce the registration, the officer had the right to check the vehicle identification number and ask the passenger to help him look for the registration.Â  He found no constitutional violation with the casual conversation the officer carried on with the passenger while he looked for the registration.Â  He further determined whether Jones gave consent to search the vehicle was irrelevant inasmuch as there was no search carried out pursuant to the alleged consent since Patterson jumped out of the car and ran, throwing objects to the ground after having been detained for, at most, around eleven minutes.Â  The trial judge therefore denied the motion to suppress.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jones appeals his conviction arguing the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the crack cocaine recovered in this case because it was tainted fruit seized as the result of an illegal detention.Â  We disagree.Â  
Jones relies largely on the case of State v. Williams, 351 S.C. 591, 571 S.E.2d 703 (Ct. App. 2002), asserting when the officer obtained his registration and license and the license check revealed nothing, the investigatory purpose of the speeding ticket was complete.Â  He thus argues his questioning, along with that of the two passengers, as well as the call for backup amounted to an illegal detention exceeding the scope of the traffic stop.Â  
In Williams, a police officer stopped a vehicle for a possible insurance violation and discovered the vehicleâ€™s tag had been suspended for lack of insurance.Â  The officer ran a license check on the driver and found, although his driving record was clean at that time, the driverâ€™s license had previously been suspended for a controlled substance violation.Â  The officer asked the driver to step outside the vehicle while he issued a citation for the tag violation.Â  The officer wrote and explained the ticket to the driver and returned the license and registration to the driver stating, â€œBefore you leave, let me ask you a few questions.â€Â  The officer then proceeded to ask the driver a series of questions, including where he was coming from and where he was headed.Â  He also asked the driver the name of his passenger and what their relationship was.Â  As the officer was speaking with the driver, a K-9 officer arrived after a request for backup was made.Â  The officer who made the traffic stop then began to question the passenger, Williams.Â  When Williams gave inconsistent answers to that of the driver, these inconsistencies, along with knowledge of the driverâ€™s previous license suspension, led the officer to request consent to search the vehicle.Â  The officers ultimately found a twenty-five pound block of marijuana in a suitcase to which Williams had acknowledged ownership.Â  At a pretrial hearing, the officer admitted he did not follow his normal procedure when issuing a traffic citation of returning the driverâ€™s license, explaining the ticket, asking the driver if he has any questions, and allowing the driver to then leave.Â  The officer further agreed his only basis for questioning the driver further was the driverâ€™s previous license suspension for a drug violation.Â  Id.Â  at 595-96, 571 S.E.2d at 705-06.
The trial judge in Williams granted the motion to suppress finding the search was illegal because the officer lacked reasonable suspicion to question the driver and Williams beyond the scope of the traffic stop.Â  Id. at 596, 571 S.E.2d at 706.Â  The State appealed, and this court affirmed, finding â€œ[t]he marijuana found in Williamsâ€™ suitcase was discovered through an illegal detention accompanied by a lack of valid consent.â€Â  Id. at 605, 571 S.E.2d at 711.
We find Williams to be easily distinguishable from the case at hand.Â  In Williams, the driver and passenger were clearly detained beyond the scope of the traffic stop.Â  There, the officer had written and explained the ticket to the driver and had returned his license and registration before he began questioning the driver.Â  We further noted in Williams that the driver and passenger had been detained between twenty-five and forty minutes as opposed to the officerâ€™s normal stop time of nine to eleven minutes, and the officer there did not otherwise follow his normal procedure for a traffic stop.Â  Id.Â  at 602, 571 S.E.2d at 709.Â  In Williams, we held:

Once a motor vehicle is detained lawfully for a traffic violation, the police may order the driver to exit the vehicle without violating Fourth Amendment proscriptions on unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  Pennsylvania v. Mimms, 434 U.S. 106, 111 n. 6, 98 S.Ct. 330, 54 L.Ed.2d 331 (1977).Â  In carrying out the stop, an officer â€œâ€˜may request a driverâ€™s license and vehicle registration, run a computer check, and issue a citation.â€™â€Â Â  United States v. Sullivan, 138 F.3d 126, 131 (4th Cir. 1998) (citation omitted).Â  However, â€œ[a]ny further detention for questioning is beyond the scope of the [] stop and therefore illegal unless the officer has a reasonable suspicion of a serious crime.â€Â  Id. Â (emphasis added); see Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. 491, 500, 103 S.Ct. 1319, 75 L.Ed.2d 229 (1983) (plurality opinion) (â€œ[A]n investigative detention must be temporary and last no longer than is necessary to effectuate the purpose of the stop.â€); Ferris v. State, 355 Md. 356, 735 A.2d 491, 499 (1999) (â€œOnce the purpose of [the] stop has been fulfilled, the continued detention of the car and the occupants amounts to a second detention.â€).Â  The question, then, is whether Blajszczak detained, i.e. â€œseizedâ€ Williams anew, thereby triggering the Fourth Amendment and possibly rendering his consent invalid, or simply initiated a consensual encounter invoking no constitutional scrutiny.Â  See Ferris, 735 A.2d at 500 (stating the difficult question was whether the trooperâ€™s questioning of Ferris after he issued a citation and returned his driverâ€™s license and registration â€œconstituted a detention, and hence raise[d] any Fourth Amendment concerns, or was merely a â€˜consensual encounter[]â€™ . . . implicating no constitutional overviewâ€).

Id.Â  at 598-99, 571 S.E.2d at 707-08.Â  
In the case at hand, there is no question but that the vehicle was detained lawfully for a traffic violation and Trooper Elrod was allowed to request Jones exit the vehicle without violating Fourth Amendment proscriptions on unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  Unlike the Williams case, there was no further detention for questioning beyond the scope of the stop here.Â  Trooper Elrod did not question Jones and his passengers after he had returned Jonesâ€™ license and registration.Â  To the contrary, Trooper Elrod had not completed the issuance of the traffic ticket, and the purpose of the original stop had not yet been fulfilled when Patterson jumped from the car and ran, throwing objects to the ground.Â  Although Jones alluded in his argument to the trial judge that Trooper Elrod essentially extended the stop beyond a reasonable time by going on a â€œfishing expeditionâ€ prior to the issuance of the ticket, there is evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s determination that the detention was not for an unreasonably long time, the extension of time was attributable to the additional time required in obtaining the car registration, and the questions asked of Jones and the passengers did not exceed the scope of the traffic stop such as would convert the stop into an illegal detention.Â  
We find further support for our decision in the recent United States Supreme Court decision Illinois v. Caballes, No. 03-923, 2005 WL 123826 (U.S. Sup. Ct. Jan. 24, 2005).Â  In Caballes, a trooper stopped motorist Caballes for speeding on an interstate.Â  When the officer reported the traffic stop to dispatch, a second trooper overheard the transmission and immediately headed for the scene with his narcotics-detection dog.Â  The first trooper had Caballes in his patrol car and was in the process of writing a warning ticket when the second trooper walked the dog around Caballesâ€™ vehicle and the dog alerted at the trunk.Â  A subsequent search of the trunk resulted in the discovery of marijuana.Â  The trial judge, finding the officers had not unnecessarily prolonged the stop, denied Caballesâ€™ motion to suppress the evidence, and Caballes was convicted of a narcotics offense.Â  The Appellate Court affirmed, but the Illinois Supreme Court subsequently reversed the conviction finding the use of the dog unjustifiably enlarged the scope of a routine traffic stop.Â  Id.Â  at *1.Â  The U.S. Supreme Court vacated and remanded, noting they â€œaccept[ed] the state courtâ€™s conclusion that the duration of the stop . . . was entirely justified by the traffic offense and the ordinary inquiries incident to such a stop.â€Â  Id. Â at *2.
In the case at hand, there is evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s findings and we cannot say his findings are clearly erroneous.Â  We therefore find no abuse of discretion.Â  See State v. Wilson,
345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (holding in a criminal case the appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence unless the findings are clearly erroneous, and its review extends only to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion); State v. Green, 341 S.C. 214, 219 n.3, 532 S.E.2d 896, 898 n.3 (Ct. App. 2000), (holding â€œthe appellate standard of review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding and the appellate court may only reverse where there is clear error.â€).
For the foregoing reasons, Jonesâ€™ conviction isÂ Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Johnny McMillan, Jimmie Griner and Hughsie
Trowell,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Agriculture,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Luke N. Brown, Jr., Special Referee

Opinion No. 3963
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Andrew F. Lindemann and William H. Davidson, II, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
John E. Parker and Ronnie L. Crosby, both of Hampton, for Respondents.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  The South Carolina Department of Agriculture (SCDA) appeals the decision of the special referee finding Johnny McMillan and Jimmie Griner (collectively Respondents) were entitled to recover damages, pre-judgment interest, and attorneyâ€™s fees from the Warehouse Receipts Guaranty Fund. [1]Â  We affirm in part, and reverse in part.
FACTS
McMillan and Griner are farmers in Hampton County.Â  Each contracted with Hampton County Warehouse (the warehouse) to store cotton.Â  The warehouse was a licensed facility by the SCDA pursuant to sections 39-22-10 through â€“200 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  McMillan stored 1,180 bales of cotton and Griner stored 358 bales of cotton. 
In addition to contracting with the warehouse for storage, Respondents both contracted with Sea Island Cotton Trading Company (the broker) to sell the cotton.[2]Â  Approximately three months after entering the contract with the broker, Respondents each received an advance of 80 percent of the market price for cotton at that time with the understanding that when the market price increased the cotton would be sold as authorized by Respondents. Although warehouse receipts for the cotton indicated ownership was transferred to the broker, it is unclear from the record when this took place.Â  
The warehouse and the broker each declared bankruptcy in 1998.Â  Respondents were unable to sell their cotton and failed to collect the remaining 20 percent owed for the cotton.Â  Pursuant to the Warehouse Receipts Guaranty Fund and section 39-22-15 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), Respondents filed claims with SCDA to recover the 20 percent loss they claim resulted from the warehouseâ€™s bankruptcy.Â  The former director of SCDA denied the claims.Â  In the denials, he noted the receipts indicating a sale to the broker and suggested Respondents seek other legal action.Â  The denial makes no mention of any further administrative remedy, including no mention of an appeal of his decision.
Respondents then filed claims in bankruptcy court, seeking to collect the losses.Â  However, the bankruptcy court, upon a finding that ownership was never transferred to the broker and remained with Respondents, rejected the claims.Â  
Respondents then filed the underlying action, seeking to collect a â€œlossâ€ from the Warehouse Receipts Guaranty Fund.Â  SCDA filed a motion for summary judgment, arguing Respondents failed to exhaust their administrative remedies prior to bringing suit in circuit court.Â  Circuit Court Judge Diane Goodstein denied the motion. 
The Honorable Luke Brown, acting as special referee, heard the claim.Â  At the hearing, McMillan and Griner each testified regarding their transactions with the warehouse and the broker.Â  Both maintained they never sold the cotton to the broker, but merely received an advance.Â  Each asserted ownership should not have been transferred to the broker.
Additionally, Louie Conder, former director of the warehouse system, testified extensively regarding the receipts issued to the broker and whether the receipts were proper under the statute or the regulations.Â  He also testified Respondents had not been paid the full amount for their cotton.
The referee found Respondents had not transferred ownership of the cotton to the broker and the receipts were not valid.Â  The referee concluded Respondents demonstrated a â€œlossâ€ under section 39-22-15 and were entitled to recover the 20 percent still owed for the cotton.Â  He also found Respondents were entitled to recover pre-judgment interest and attorneyâ€™s fees.
SCDA filed a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 52(b), SCRCP. The referee denied SCDAâ€™s requested relief.Â  He found the action was not an appeal from an administrative decision, and Respondents were not required to exhaust administrative remedies.Â  Finally, the referee set the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Respondents.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Exhaustion of Administrative Remedies
SCDA contends the referee erred in finding Respondents were not required to exhaust their administrative remedies prior to filing suit in circuit court for damages.Â  Additionally, SCDA maintains because section 22 of Article I of the South Carolina Constitution provides due process and requires an opportunity for an individual to be heard, Respondents still had administrative remedies that could be pursued.Â  We disagree and find nothing requiring Respondents to exhaust administrative rights prior to bringing this action in circuit court.
First, this issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  A party must raise the issue of the exhaustion of administrative remedies and receive a ruling by the trial court in order to preserve it for review on appeal.Â 
Food Mart v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 322 S.C. 232, 233, 471 S.E.2d 688, 688 (1996).Â  â€œA denial of a motion for summary judgment does not establish the law of the case, and the issues raised in the motion may be raised later in the proceedings.â€Â  Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 416, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
While SCDA raised the issue in a summary judgment motion prior to trial, the issue was never raised to the referee until SCDA made its motion to alter or amend under Rule 52(b), SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, the issue is not preserved because it cannot be raised for the first time in a motion to alter or amend.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€). 
The Administrative Procedures Act (APA) provides for judicial review of a contested case after agency action upon the partyâ€™s exhaustion of administrative remedies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (2005).Â  Pursuant to section 1-23-310(3) of the South Carolina Code: â€œâ€˜Contested caseâ€™ means a proceeding including, but not restricted to, ratemaking, price fixing, and licensing, in which the legal rights, duties, or privileges of a party are required by law to be determined by an agency after an opportunity for hearing.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-310(3) (2005).
This court explicated:

â€œThe doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies only comes into play when a litigant attempts to invoke the original jurisdiction of a circuit court to adjudicate a claim based on a statutory violation for which the legislature has provided an administrative remedy.â€Â  Med. Mut. Liab. Ins. Soc. of Md. v. B. Dixon Evander & Assocs., 92 Md. App. 551, 609 A.2d 353 (1992).Â  A litigant need not exhaust administrative remedies where â€œthere are no administrative remedies for the wrongs it assertedly suffered.â€Â  Id. at 360.Â Â Â  

Thomas Sand Co. v. Colonial Pipeline Co., 349 S.C. 402, 413, 563 S.E.2d 109, 115 (Ct. App. 2002).
In the instant case, a statutory procedure does not exist to provide an administrative remedy.Â  There is no â€œcontested caseâ€ for which the provisions of the APA would apply.Â  As additional proof of the lack of remedies, the denial by the director of SCDA does not point to any further administrative avenues available to Respondents.Â  The director of SCDA suggests bankruptcy or other legal proceedings may be available to Respondents.Â  The denial does not mention the availability of an appeal or subsequent hearing of any type.Â  Accordingly, as there are no administrative remedies set forth and available to Respondents, they should not be barred from bringing this action in circuit court.
Section 22 of Article I of the South Carolina Constitution states:

No person shall be finally bound by a judicial or quasi-judicial decision of an administrative agency affecting private rights except on due notice and an opportunity to be heard; nor shall he be subject to the same person for both prosecution and adjudication;Â  nor shall he be deprived of liberty or property unless by a mode of procedure prescribed by the General Assembly, and he shall have in all such instances the right to judicial review.

S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 22.
In discussing Section 22 of Article I, the South Carolina Supreme Court explained:

In recognition of the increasing number of governmental powers delegated to administrative agencies, South Carolina Constitution article I, Â§ 22 was added to the 1895 Constitution in 1970 â€œas a safeguard for the protection of liberty and property of citizens.â€Â  Final Report of the Committee to Make a Study of the South Carolina Constitution of 1895, p. 21 (1969).
. . . 
We have interpreted this provision as specifically guaranteeing persons the right to notice and an opportunity to be heard by an administrative agency, even when a contested case under the APA is not involved.Â  Stono River EPA v. Department of Health and Environmental Control, 305 S.C. 90, 406 S.E.2d 340 (1991).Â  

Ross v. Med. Univ. of South Carolina, 328 S.C. 51, 68, 492 S.E.2d 62, 71 (1997).
Respondents filed a claim with SCDA, which was ultimately denied.Â  Respondents have not claimed a violation of their due process rights under section 22 of Article I.Â  Nor have they asserted they were deprived of notice or an opportunity to be heard.Â  They have brought suit seeking to collect money damages owed pursuant to a statutorily created reimbursement fund.Â  It does not appear section 22 of Article I was intended to be used by the agency to force a claimant to proceed under the Administrative Procedures Act when the agency does not have a procedure in place.Â  Accordingly, we find the referee properly determined Respondents were not required to exhaust any additional administrative remedies prior to brining suit in circuit court.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Type of Action
SCDA asserts the referee failed in determining the type of action involved in the underlying case.Â  The SCDA avers the action is an appeal from an administrative agency or an action under the Tort Claims Act and not an action for money damages.Â  We find the issue is not preserved for review on appeal and, on the merits, the action would be in the nature of a declaratory judgment action or an action for money damages under a statute.
This issue was never raised to the referee for a ruling or a determination prior to the courtâ€™s issuance of its final order.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Additionally, the first time it was raised to the court was in SCDAâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  It is not appropriate to raise an issue for the first time in a Rule 52(b) motion that could have been raised at trial.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€). 
As discussed above, this case is not a continuation of an administrative process.Â  There is no provision in the code or the regulations allowing for administrative hearings or requiring the Warehouse Receipts Guaranty Fund to follow the APA.Â  Thus, SCDAâ€™s argument that this case is nothing more than an appeal of an administrative decision is without merit.
Additionally, this case does not fall within the auspices of the Tort Claims Act, section 15-78-10 of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  â€œThe Tort Claims Act governs all tort claims against governmental entities and is the exclusive civil remedy available in an action against the government.â€Â  Washington v. Lexington County Jail, 337 S.C. 400, 404, 523 S.E.2d 204, 206 (Ct. App. 1999) (emphasis added).Â  This is not a case in which Respondents brought suit based upon the governmentâ€™s negligence or to redress a tort committed by SCDA.Â  They are bringing a suit to collect monetary damages pursuant to a section of the South Carolina Code, which establishes the fund to pay those damages.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in finding the appeal was not covered by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.
While section 39-22-15 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) does not specifically authorize a suit to collect money owed from the fund, it is clear the only means of redress would be a cause of action against the Warehouse Guaranty Fund for monetary damages or a declaratory judgment action.Â  Accordingly, we find the underlying action is an action to collect monetary damages pursuant to statute, which authorizes the payment for a â€œloss.â€
III.Â Â Â  Loss
SCDA contends Respondents failed to prove they suffered a loss as a result of having cotton stored with the warehouse.Â  SCDA maintains Respondentsâ€™ loss is the result of the bankruptcy of the broker and not in any way connected to the storage of the cotton at the warehouse.Â  We disagree.
According to section 39-22-15 of the South Carolina Code:

For purposes of this chapter, â€œlossâ€ means any monetary loss over and beyond the amount protected by a warehousemanâ€™s bond sustained as a result of storing a commodity in a state-licensed warehouse including, but not limited to, any monetary loss over and beyond the amount protected by a warehousemanâ€™s bond sustained as a result of the warehousemanâ€™s bankruptcy, embezzlement, or fraud.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-22-15 (Supp. 2004).
Respondents each stored cotton in the warehouse at the time it declared bankruptcy.Â  At that time, Respondents had each been paid an 80 percent advance by the broker and were waiting to sell their cotton to collect the remaining 20 percent.Â  SCDA claims the loss was the result of the bankruptcy of the broker and not of the warehouse.Â  SCDA asserts any additional payment to Respondents would have been from the broker.Â  However, this ignores the fact that the warehouse also declared bankruptcy, thereby preventing Respondents from selling their cotton, whether through the broker or in any other fashion.
Section 39-22-15 only requires the parties to have suffered a loss â€œas a result of storing a commodity in a state-licensed warehouse.â€Â  This occurred when the warehouse declared bankruptcy and Respondents were unable to sell their cotton for an appropriate price to recover the remaining 20 percent owed to them after their advance.Â  Accordingly, we find Respondents demonstrated they suffered a loss compensable under section 39-22-15.
IV.Â Â Â  Receipts
SCDA contends the referee erred in finding Respondentsâ€™ cotton was not sold to the broker.Â  SCDA asserts the court erred in relying upon section 39-22-200 of the South Carolina Code and Regulation 5-493 to find the receipts issued by the warehouse were invalid and no transfer of the cotton occurred.Â  We disagree.
Section 39-22-200 of the South Carolina Code states in pertinent part:

A state warehouse receipt must be issued by the warehouseman to a person storing commodities who requests it. . . . No receipt may be issued in the name of the storing warehouse, or its owners, on commodities being purchased by the warehouse until the commodity has been paid for in full, even if a contract has been executed establishing that the title to the commodity has passed to the warehouse or its owners unless the buyer and seller execute an affidavit within the contract stating that the seller conveys title and ownership of the commodity and forfeits all of his rights under the Dealer and Handler Guaranty Fund.Â  

S.C. Code. Ann. Â§ 39-22-200 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  Additionally, regulation 5-493 provides:

G. A warehouse receipt shall not be issued in the name of the purchaser of any commodity being purchased on a deferred-price, delayed payment or similar credit-type sale arrangement until the seller has received payment for the commodity in full unless he has executed the affidavit relinquishing title and ownership to the buyer and forfeiting his rights under the Dealers and Handlers Guaranty Fund and has fully complied with the requirements set out in Section 39-22-200.

23 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 5-493(G) (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  Finally, the definition of â€œcommodityâ€ is contained in regulation 5-490:

G. â€œCommodityâ€ means:
(1) Cotton.
(2) â€œNon-perishable farm productâ€ as defined by definition (F) or which may hereafter be included in this special definition.

23 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 5-490(G) (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).
â€œThe words of a statute or regulation â€˜must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand its operation.â€™â€Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 563, 590 S.E.2d 338, 355 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992)); see also Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 97 (2002) (â€œWhen the statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous, there is no room for an alternate construction, and courts must apply them according to their literal meaning.â€).
Initially, we disagree with SCDAâ€™s contention that section 39-22-200 has no application in this case.Â  Although the section applies to â€œcommodities being purchased by the warehouse,â€ the circumstances of this case come within the ambit of that limitation.Â  Griner testified that David Prosser was a broker with the Hampton County Warehouse, but was also the principal in Sea Island Cotton Trading Company.Â  A review of the articles of incorporation for both entities confirms Prosserâ€™s dual involvement.Â  Thus, even though the receipts in this case were issued to the broker and not the warehouse, that alone not would not preclude the application of section 39-22-200 given the Hampton County Warehouse and Sea Island Cotton Trading Company were essentially the same entity.Â  Applying the requirements of section 39-22-200, we find the transfer from the Hampton County Warehouse was invalid given payment had not been made in full and the requisite affidavit conveying title and ownership of the cotton was not executed.Â  
Furthermore, regulation 5-493 does not limit the purchaser to the warehouse.Â  It expressly states: â€œA warehouse receipt shall not be issued in the name of the purchaser of any commodity being purchased on a deferred-price, delayed payment or similar credit-type sale arrangement until the seller has received payment for the commodity in full.â€Â  As defined in regulation 5-490, cotton is a commodity and would be covered by regulation 5-493.Â  
SCDA maintains because regulation 5-493 requires the waiver of rights under the Dealer and Handler Guaranty Fund, and not the Warehouse Guaranty Fund, it should not be applicable.Â  While it does reference the rights under one fund and not the other, there is nothing limiting it to claims under the Dealer and Handler Guaranty Fund.Â  The first portion states very clearly how the regulation is to apply, and it explicitly prohibits issuing a receipt in the name of any purchaser of any commodity unless the seller has received full payment.Â  See Ferguson, 349 S.C. at 563, 564 S.E.2d at 97Â  (â€œWhen the statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous, there is no room for an alternate construction, and courts must apply them according to their literal meaning.â€).
The receipts in the instant case were issued in the name of the broker, even though Respondents had not received full payment from the broker.Â  Accordingly, under section 39-22-200 and regulation 5-493, the receipts were improperly issued and were not evidence of a sale of the cotton to the broker.Â  Additionally, refusal to provide payment from the fund on the ground that the receipts were not issued in Respondentsâ€™ name is not proper.Â  Accordingly, we find the referee correctly concluded the receipts were invalid and ownership of the cotton remained with Respondents based upon the amounts they placed in the warehouse respectively.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Pre-judgment Interest
SCDA asserts the referee erred in awarding Respondents pre-judgment interest.Â  SCDA avers pre-judgment interest must be specifically pled, and Respondents failed to properly plead a claim for pre-judgment interest.Â  In addition, SCDA contends Respondentsâ€™ motion to amend the pleading was not sufficient to raise the claim.Â  We agree.
â€œIn all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(A) (1987). Pre-judgment interest must be specifically pled in order to be recovered.Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 307, 540 S.E.2d 454, 458 (2000); Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 102, 529 S.E.2d 14, 18 (2000).Â Â  â€œIf no request for pre-judgment interest is made in the pleadings, it cannot be recovered on appeal.â€Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 375, 585 S.E.2d 292, 299 (2003).Â  
Rule 15(b), SCRCP, governs amendments to conform to the evidence.Â  â€œThe rule covers two situations.Â  First, if an issue not raised by the pleadings is tried by express or implied consent of the parties the court may permit amendment of the pleadings to reflect the issue.Â  Second, if a party objects to the introduction of evidence as not being within the pleadings the court may permit amendment of the pleadings subject to a right to grant a continuance if necessary.â€Â  Sunvillas Homeowners Assâ€™n, v. Square D Co., 301 S.C. 330, 334, 391 S.E.2d 868, 870-71 (Ct. App. 1990).
In the instant case, there is no dispute Respondents failed to ask for pre-judgment interest in their complaints.Â  The dispute is whether their motion to amend the complaint to conform to the evidence was sufficient to properly raise the issue. 
At trial, when Respondents attempted through Grinerâ€™s testimony to enter into evidence the issue of pre-judgment interest, SCDA objected.Â  After the objection the court indicated:Â  â€œAll right.Â  Iâ€™ll look at [the complaint].Â  Go ahead.Â  And Iâ€™ll note your objection.â€Â  Nothing further was ever ruled upon by the court.Â  During McMillanâ€™s testimony, interest was mentioned a second time.Â  However, it was a vague reference to the amount was owed.Â  In addition, SCDA did not specifically object to the comment. 
At the end of trial, Respondents stated:Â  â€œI was just going to move to amend our pleadings to conform to any evidence to the extent thereâ€™s evidence outside, you know, that - - but I donâ€™t think there is.â€Â  The court responded:Â  â€œWell, I took the position that it asked for everything.Â  I read your part of the complaint.â€ Â No objection was made by SCDA. 
We do not find the motion made by Respondents was sufficient to properly amend the complaint to include a claim for pre-judgment interest, which must be specifically pled in order to be recovered.Â  The motion was extremely general and not completely clear.Â  Additionally, in making the motion, Respondentsâ€™ counsel indicated he does not believe there is any evidence outside the complaint when he moves to â€œconform to any evidence to the extent thereâ€™s evidence outside, you know, that - - but I donâ€™t think there is.â€ (Emphasis added.)Â  Accordingly, we find this motion was insufficient to properly raise the issue of pre-judgment interest.Â  Because the issue was not pled in the complaint, nor included within the motion to amend, we find the referee erred in awarding pre-judgment interest.Â  Tilley, 355 S.C. at 375, 585 S.E.2d at 299.Â  
VI.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Finally, SCDA asserts the referee erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees because the statute does not provide for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree and find the award appropriate.
We agree the statute does not specifically provide for recovery of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, the code section does not explicitly exclude the attorneyâ€™s fees as a â€œlossâ€ to be recovered.Â  In the instant case, we need not determine whether attorneyâ€™s fees would be included as a â€œlossâ€ under section 39-22-15, because we find attorneyâ€™s fees are collectible under section 15-77-300 of the South Carolina Code.
Section 15-77-300 provides in part:

In any civil action brought by . . . any party who is contesting state action, . . ., the court may allow the prevailing party to recover reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees to be taxed as court costs against the appropriate agency if:
(1) The court finds that the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim against the party; and
(2) The court finds that there are no special circumstances that would make the award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (2005).
â€œOn appeal, the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding an award of attorneyâ€™s fees under this statute will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€ Jasper County Bd. of Educ. v. Jasper County Grand Jury, 303 S.C. 49, 51, 398 S.E.2d 498, 499 (1990).
We find Respondents are clearly the prevailing parties in this action.Â  Thus, we must determine whether they have shown SCDA acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim and no special circumstances exist to make the award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust. 
In Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 394 S.E.2d 709 (1990), the supreme court held â€œsubstantial justification,â€ for the purposes of this statute, means justified to a degree that could satisfy a reasonable person.Â  Heath, 302 S.C. at 183, 394 S.E.2d at 712.Â  â€œAn agency action supported by substantial justification is one which has a reasonable basis in law and fact.â€ McDowell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 304 S.C. 539, 542, 405 S.E.2d 830, 832 (1991) (citing Pierce v. Underwood, 487 U.S. 552 (1988)).Â Â  
In determining whether there was substantial justification in this case, we look to the substance and outcome of the underlying matter.Â  We find SCDA was without substantial justification in denying recovery from the Warehouse Guaranty Fund and in claiming Respondents must pursue administrative remedies that are not in place.Â  We see no reason or circumstance to declare the award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.Â  Accordingly, we find the award of attorneyâ€™s fees by the referee was proper under section 15-77-300.
CONCLUSION
We find the referee properly concluded this was an action for money damages pursuant to a statute and Respondents were not required to pursue any additional administrative remedies prior to bringing suit under section 39-22-15.Â  Additionally, we find the trial court properly concluded there was no sale of the cotton from Respondents to the broker, and Respondents proved they suffered a loss as a result of storing the cotton at the warehouse.Â  Therefore, we conclude the award of the remaining 20 percent was proper.Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees was also justified under section 15-77-300.Â  However, we find the award of pre-judgment interest was improper when it was not properly pled and Respondentsâ€™ motion to amend did not specifically include the claim for pre-judgment interest.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the referee is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  
Because Hughsie Trowellâ€™s claim was paid in full, he is not a party in this appeal.
[2]Â Â  Hampton County Warehouse and Sea Island Cotton Trading Company were both owned by David Prosser.
