title: Jones v. State Farm Mutual
description: In this civil appeal, the issue is whether section 38-77-120 mandates that an insurance company notify an insured that the insured has not been ceded to the Reinsurance Facility.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Terry K. Jones, Appellant,
v.
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3964
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gary W. Poliakoff, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Michael T. Cole and Charles R. Norris, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Terry K. Jones (Jones) initiated this action against State Farm Automobile Insurance Company (State Farm) seeking a declaration that his 1986 Mazda pickup truck was covered under a State Farm policy at the time he was involved in an automobile collision.Â  The trial judge entered summary judgment in favor of State Farm, finding that State Farm had cancelled coverage on the 1986 Mazda prior to the accident.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
As late as November of 1999, State Farm provided insurance for three of Jonesâ€™s vehicles, including the 1986 Mazda pickup truck.Â  However, on November 5, 1999, State Farm sent a cancellation notice informing Jones that effective November 24, 1999, coverage of the 1986 Mazda would be cancelled due to nonpayment of premiums. 
On December 19, 1999, Jones was seriously injured in a motor vehicle collision with Arthur W. Campbell.Â  Jones had been driving the 1986 Mazda.Â  Sometime after the accident, Jonesâ€™s State Farm agent signed a Form FR-10 which stated: â€œI hereby affirm that to the best of my knowledge the vehicle described above was insured by State Farm insurance company on the date and time of the accident.â€Â Â Â  
Jonesâ€™s medical bills exceeded $200,000.Â  After settling with Campbellâ€™s liability carrier, Jones sought a declaration that (1) the 1986 Mazda was covered by State Farm at the time of the collision, (2) he was entitled to $50,000 of underinsured motorist coverage on the Mazda, and (3) he was entitled to stack $50,000 of underinsured motorist coverage from each of the two additional vehicles covered by State Farm.Â  State Farm moved for summary judgment, claiming the policy had been cancelled. 
The trial judge ruled that State Farm was entitled to summary judgment because State Farmâ€™s cancellation notice complied with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-120 (1985), and the Form FR-10 did not affect the cancellation. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 360 S.C. 366, 601 S.E.2d 342 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied.Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); Rife v. Hitachi Const. Mach. Co., Ltd., Op. No. 3936 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 28, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 7 at 48).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Belton v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 360 S.C. 575, 602 S.E.2d 289 (2004); McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004); Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  McCall, 359 S.C. at 376, 597 S.E.2d at 183. Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial. Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004); Peterson v. West American Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 593 S.E.2d 183 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004); Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 594 S.E.2d 557 (Ct. App. 2004); Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 542 S.E.2d 743 (Ct. App. 2001).
The determination of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  City of Myrtle Beach v. Juel P. Corp., 344 S.C. 43, 543 S.E.2d 538 (2001); Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995); Goldston v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 358 S.C. 157, 594 S.E.2d 511 (Ct. App. 2004); Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Johnson v. Pratt, 200 S.C. 315, 20 S.E.2d 865 (1942) (acknowledging that statutory construction is the province of the courts); Thompson v. Ford Motor Co., 200 S.C. 393, 21 S.E.2d 34 (1942) (noting that the interpretation of the meaning of a statutory term is not a finding of fact).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Requirements of Â§ 38-77-120
Jones argues the trial judge erred in granting summary judgment to State Farm because the cancellation notice mailed to Jones did not comply with the requirements of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-120 (2002).Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 38-77-120 provides, in pertinent part:

(a)Â  No cancellation . . . is effective unless the insurer delivers or mails to the named insured at the address shown in the policy a written notice of the cancellation . . . .Â  This notice:
  
(1) must be approved as to form by the director or his designee before use;
(2) must state the date not less than fifteen days after the date of the mailing or delivering on which the cancellation or refusal to renew becomes effective;
(3) must state the specific reason of the insurer for cancellation . . . and provide for the notification required by subsection (B) of Section 38-77-390 . . . . 
(4) must inform the insured of his right to request in writing within fifteen days of the receipt of notice that the director review the action of the insurer. . . . 
(5) must inform the insured of the possible availability of other insurance which may be obtained through his agent, through another insurer, or through the Associated Auto Insurers Plan.Â  It must also state that the Department of Insurance has available an automobile insurance buyerâ€™s guide regarding automobile insurance shopping and availability, and provide applicable mailing addresses and telephone numbers, including a toll-free number, if available, for contacting the Department of Insurance. 
  
Nothing in this subsection prohibits any insurer or agent from including in the notice of cancellation . . . , any additional disclosure statements required by state or federal laws, or any additional information relating to the availability of other insurance.Â  The insurer must disclose in writing whether the insured is ceded to the facility.  

S.C. Code Ann. (2002) (emphasis added).Â  The language at the center of this logomachy is the last sentence of Â§ 38-77-120(a)â€”â€œThe insurer must disclose in writing whether the insured is ceded to the facility.â€Â  State Farm concedes it did not notify Jones that he was not being ceded to the Reinsurance Facility and contends Â§ 38-77-120 does not require it to do so.
 A.Â  Rules of Statutory Interpretation Â Â Â Â  
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature.Â  Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils. Inc., Op. No. 25930 (S.C. filed January 24, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 4 at 44) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€); Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 344 S.C. 194, 205, 544 S.E.2d 38, 44 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe quintessence of statutory construction is legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 567 S.E.2d 240 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen v. Avins Const. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent of the General Assembly.Â  Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 564 S.E.2d 358 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Comm'n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); Cowan v. Allstate Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 626, 631, 571 S.E.2d 715, 717 (Ct. App. 2002); Olson, 344 S.C. at 207, 544 S.E.2d at 45; see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not in the legislature's language.â€).Â  When the terms of a statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Cooper v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002); Holley v. Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 320, 440 S.E.2d 373 (1994); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will. Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001). The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996); Worsley Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 102, 567 S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (observing that where the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language).Â  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; see also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€). An ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Dep't v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In construing a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560, 486 S.E.2d at 494.
â€œA statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.Â  The real purpose and intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the literal import of the words.â€Â  Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 125, 414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579 S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€); Municipal Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT & T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468 (2004) (observing that the language of a statute must be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose).Â  
Courts will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 529 S.E.2d 280 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994).Â  A court should not consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  See Hinton v. South Carolina Dept. of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327, 592 S.E.2d 335 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Jan. 12, 2005); Doe v. Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 578 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied. 
B.Â  Interpretation of Â§ 38-77-120
The â€œfacilityâ€ referred to in Â§ 38-77-120 is the South Carolina Reinsurance Facility (the Facility) created by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-510.Â  â€œThe South Carolina Reinsurance Facility . . . is a nonprofit organization which enables automobile insurers to obtain reinsurance for high risk drivers which they normally would not insure.â€Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Lindsay, 288 S.C. 327, 328, 342 S.E.2d 599, 599 (1986).Â  The Facility is soon to be defunct, however, due to Act. No. 154 Â§ (1997), which repealed Â§Â§ 38-77-510 through -640 effective January 1, 2006.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-590(g), â€œA producer designated under this section may not write new private passenger and commercial automobile insurance business to be placed in the facility after March 1, 1999.Â  A policy with an effective date after March 1, 2002 shall not be accepted by the facility.â€Â  S.C. Code Â§Â§ 38-91-10 through â€“420 created the Joint Underwriting Association to temporarily replace the Facility as the primary residual market mechanism from March 1, 1999 through February 28, 2003.Â  See Note, Lifting the Iron Curtain of Automobile Insurance Regulation, 49 S.C.L.Rev. 1193, 1207 (Summer 1998).Â  Currently, the Associated Auto Insurers Plan serves as the residual market mechanism.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 38-77-810 through â€“880 (2002). See generally Maybank et al., The Law of Automobile Insurance in South Carolina I-74 â€“ I-98 (4th ed. 2000); Lifting the Iron Curtain, 49 S.C.L.Rev. 1193.
Undisputedly, Â§ 38-77-120 required an insurance company to notify an insured when he or she had been ceded to the Facility.Â  This requirement served to notify the insured that he or she had been deemed a high-risk driver subject to recoupment charges.Â  See Lifting the Iron Curtain, 49 S.C.L.Rev. n.167 (noting that former Â§ 38-77-600 set a recoupment fee to cover operating losses the Facility incurred during the preceding year).Â  However, State Farm contends, and we agree, that an insurer is not required to inform the insured he or she has not been ceded to the Facility.Â  We do not believe that Jonesâ€™s specious construction of Â§ 38-77-120 comports with the intent of that section.Â  
Section 38-77-120 serves to put on notice drivers whose policies are being cancelled or will not be renewed.Â  In subsection (a), the statute sets forth five mandates aimed at giving the insured adequate notice of the cancellation of his or her policy.Â  The notice must: (1) be approved by the Director; (2) state the effective date of cancellation; (3) state the reason for cancellation; (4) inform the insured of his right to request review of the termination; and (5) provide the insured with information regarding other available sources of insurance.Â  State Farm mailed a complying cancellation notice on November 5, 1999â€”approximately forty days before the December 19 accident.Â  Jones does not contest that State Farm notified him of the cancellation of his policy.Â  
Jonesâ€™s rendering of the statute would require disclosure of a non-eventâ€”i.e., that he has not been deemed a high risk driver; therefore he will not be ceded to the Facility; and he will not be subject to recoupment fees.Â  Such an interpretation of Â§ 38-77-120 is not a practical and reasonable interpretation consistent with the design of the legislature.Â  Instead, Jonesâ€™s interpretation would â€œlead to a result so plainly absurd it could not have been intended by the legislature.â€Â  Unisun, 339 S.C. at 368, 529 S.E.2d at 283.Â  Jones states no rationale supporting a policy of requiring an insurance company to inform insureds they are not being ceded to an organization designed to facilitate the acquisition of insurance for high-risk drivers.Â  
Moreover, the sentence at issue is not one of the five enumerated mandates, but is provided in the flush paragraph at the end of the subsection.Â  The penultimate sentence of subsection (a) informs insurers that they are not prevented from providing additional information in the notice.Â  The sentence in controversy then gives one piece of additional information that must be provided.Â  Although the placement of the controverted sentence does not dictate our decision, the sentenceâ€™s location does suggest the legislature did not consider the final sentence of subsection (a) as significant as the enumerated directives.Â  
Considering the content of the sentence; the purpose of the statute; and the placement of the sentence, we hold, as a matter of law, that State Farm was not required to notify Jones that he had not been ceded to the Facility.Â  
II.Â  Effect of Form FR-10 
Jones asserts the trial judge erred in granting summary judgment because the FR-10 form signed by his insurance agent raised factual issues as to the existence of coverage.Â  We disagree.Â  
First, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  In his memorandum in opposition to summary judgment, and in his argument to the trial judge, Jones simply asserted that the Form FR-10 created an issue of fact.Â  He did not set forth a concomitant legal theory which would entitle him to recovery based on the FR-10.Â  Jones did not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  For the first time on appeal, Jones contends the Form FR-10 estops State Farm from denying coverage.Â  
An issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.Â  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 598 S.E.2d 712 (2004); United Student Aid Funds, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtâ€™l Control, 356 S.C. 266, 588 S.E.2d 599 (2003); Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000); Austin v. Specialty Transp. Services, Inc., 358 S.C. 298, 594 S.E.2d 867 (Ct. App. 2004); see also QZO, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 594 S.E.2d 485 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting it is axiomatic than an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal).Â  An issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 597 S.E.2d 897 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Jones did not present an estoppel argument to the trial judge; therefore, this issue is not preserved. 
Second, as to the merits, we find the trial judge properly granted summary judgment.Â  In a light most favorable to Jones, the FR-10 did not raise an issue as to the validity of State Farmâ€™s cancellation notice.Â  The form simply states â€œto the best of my knowledge the vehicle described above was insured by State Farm insurance company on the date and time of the accident.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  State Farm presented evidence that Jones, in fact, was not insured by State Farm at the time of the accident because his policy had been cancelled weeks earlier.Â  Jones cites no legal authority establishing that a policy, once effectively canceled, can somehow become renascent by virtue of a qualified representation of coverage by an agent after a loss.Â  
Even if Jonesâ€™s estoppel argument were properly preserved, he presented no evidence demonstrating his ability to establish the elements of estoppel.Â  In Provident Life & Acc. Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 451 S.E.2d 924 (Ct. App. 1994), we observed that â€œ[u]nder South Carolina law, the essential elements of estoppel are divided between the estopped party and the party claiming estoppel.â€Â  Id. at 477, 451 S.E.2d at 928 (citations omitted).Â  

As to the estopped party, the essential elements are: (1) conduct amounting to a false representation or concealment of material facts, or conduct calculated to convey the impression that the facts are otherwise than, and inconsistent with, the partyâ€™s subsequent assertions; (2) intention or expectation that such conduct be acted upon by the other party; and (3) actual or constructive knowledge of the real facts.Â  As to the party claiming estoppel, the essential elements are: (1) lack of knowledge or the means of acquiring, with reasonable diligence, knowledge of the true facts; (2) reasonable reliance on the other partyâ€™s conduct; and (3) a prejudicial change in position.

Id. (citations omitted).Â  Accord Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Associates, 340 S.C. 98, 531 S.E.2d 287 (2000).Â  Jones did not present evidence that State Farm made a knowingly false representation with the intent to induce Jones into action.Â  Further, Jones failed to submit evidence that he did not have notice of the cancellation, and that he detrimentally relied on the Form FR-10. 
In Bannister v. Ohio Cas. Ins. Co., 314 S.C. 388, 444 S.E.2d 528 (Ct. App. 1994), the appellant argued, â€œOhio Casualty is estopped to deny coverage because an FR-10 form was executed by one of the companyâ€™s agents.â€Â  Id. at 393, 444 S.E.2d at 531.Â  We rejected the appellantâ€™s argument, finding he â€œha[d] not demonstrated any of the elements of estoppel.â€Â  Id.Â  Similarly, Jones has failed to demonstrate any of the elements of estoppel in the instant case.Â  
Jones has not presented to this Court a reviewable argument, based on the Form FR-10, that would compel reversal of the trial judgeâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-120 does not require an insurer to notify an insured that he or she has NOT been ceded to the South Carolina Reinsurance Facility.Â  Further, the Form FR-10 did not create an issue of fact which could have entitled Jones to the relief he sought.Â  The trial judge correctly granted summary judgment in favor of State Farm.Â  Accordingly, the decision is 
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. McCall
description: In this appeal from a criminal case, Appellant Karen Ann McCall argues that her conviction should be overturned on the ground that the State should be judicially estopped from prosecuting her.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Karen Ann McCall, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3965
  Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed March 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Acting Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.: In this appeal from a criminal case, Appellant Karen Ann McCall argues that her conviction should be overturned on the ground that the State should be judicially estopped from prosecuting her.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In December 2000, John Richard Wood left the scene of an incident in Greenville County[1] on a moped scooter, weaving through heavy traffic.Â  Wood then rode behind a building, parked the scooter and got into a Jeep driven by McCall.Â  The Jeep sped off with McCall at the wheel and witnesses called the police with the Jeepâ€™s license tag number.Â  Wood and McCall fled to Anderson County where authorities located and followed them before a high-speed chase ensued.Â  The Jeepâ€™s back window rolled down and Wood fired several rounds of shots at police with a gun owned by McCall, resulting in a bullet fragment striking an officer in the head.Â  Subsequently, the Jeep rammed into a van and veered into oncoming traffic, and Wood carjacked a pickup truck. Wood and McCall continued fleeing from the police.Â  The chase ultimately ended in a standoff in which Wood was also shot.Â  
A trial of Wood was held in Greenville County and McCall was not named as a defendant.Â  She testified that she had acted under duress, arguing essentially that Wood coerced her into assisting him through threats with the gun as well as with physical force.Â  The State offered her no grant of immunity, nor made any promises or deals in order to obtain this testimony.Â  
Subsequently in Anderson County, McCall was charged with, among other things, criminal conspiracy.Â  At a pretrial hearing, McCall moved to quash the indictments, arguing that because the State called her as a witness in the Greenville trial and allowed her to testify she acted under duress, the State should be judicially estopped from prosecuting her as a co-conspirator in the Anderson case.Â  The trial court denied the motion, finding McCallâ€™s testimony in Greenville largely self-serving.Â  
After a joint trial with co-defendant Wood, where McCall asserted the defense of duress in keeping with her testimony in Greenville, the jury convicted her of criminal conspiracy, failure to stop when signaled by a law enforcement vehicle, resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, armed robbery, three counts of assault with intent to kill, one count of assault and battery with intent to kill, and one count of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  The circuit court sentenced McCall to prison for twenty-five years.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
South Carolina officially recognized the doctrine of judicial estoppel in Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 251, 489 S.E.2d 472, 477 (1997).Â  â€œJudicial estoppel precludes a party from adopting a position in conflict with one earlier taken in the same or related litigation.â€Â  Id.Â  The purpose of judicial estoppel is to protect the integrity of the courts, not to protect litigants from allegedly improper or deceitful conduct by their adversaries.Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 42, 577 S.E.2d 202, 208 (2003); see also Quinn v. Sharon Corp., 343 S.C. 411, 540 S.E.2d 474 (Ct. App. 2000) (Anderson, J., concurring) (providing a thorough discussion of the history, purpose, and application of judicial estoppel).Â  Judicial estoppel in South Carolina generally applies only to inconsistent statements of fact, not inconsistent positions of law.Â  Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 82-83, 552 S.E.2d 767, 771 (Ct. App. 2001). 
The elements of judicial estoppel are as follows: (1) two inconsistent positions taken by the same party or parties in privity with one another; (2) the positions are taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with one another; (3) the party taking the position must have been successful in maintaining that position and received some benefit; (4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and (5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent.Â  Cothran v. Brown, 357 S.C. 210, 215-16, 592 S.E.2d 629, 632 (2004).Â  
South Carolina courts have not addressed the applicability of judicial estoppel in criminal cases. Â To date, all cases involving judicial estoppel have arisen in the civil context, although one court considered applying judicial estoppel in a civil case based on a prior guilty plea.Â  Carrigg, 347 S.C. at 84, 552 S.E.2d at 772 (holding that judicial estoppel did not apply based on lack of privity).Â  North Carolina has recently rejected the use of judicial estoppel in criminal cases.Â  See Whitacre Partnership v. Biosignia, Inc., 591 S.E.2d 870 (N.C. 2004) (providing extensive discussion of the doctrine and holding that judicial estoppel applies only in civil cases). 
We need not reach the issue of whether judicial estoppel applies in criminal cases, however, because even if the doctrine applied, McCallâ€™s case fails to meet the required elements.Â  The purpose of judicial estoppel would not extend to cases such as this one.Â  Nothing in the Stateâ€™s conduct would impinge on the integrity of the courts.Â  McCall was simply permitted to testify in the prior proceeding as a fact witness. 
Secondly, judicial estoppel would not apply here because the allegedly contradictory positions involve issues of law.Â  The facts are undisputed.Â  McCall is simply arguing that the State impliedly acknowledged the validity of her defense of duress in the prior case.Â  Additionally, since McCall was not charged in Greenville, a separate judicial circuit from Anderson, the State had no reason to challenge her testimony.Â  Thirdly, the privity requirement is not met.Â  The Greenville case was against Wood and McCall was only a witness.Â  As the trial judge noted, although both cases involved the same incident involving McCall and Wood, the State did not have the same motive to cross-examine McCall. 
Finally, there is absolutely no evidence that the allegedly contradictory positions were taken in a deliberate attempt to mislead the court.Â  See Cothran, 357 S.C. at 217, 592 S.E.2d at 632 (requiring some evidence of intent to mislead).Â  The trial judge noted â€œas a fact witness, Ms. McCallâ€™s purpose was obviously to link the primary defendant, Mr. Wood, to the crimes in Greenville County.â€Â  â€œThe doctrine of judicial estoppel . . . should be applied sparingly, with clear regard for the facts of the particular case.â€Â  Id.Â  Judicial estoppel â€œmust not be applied to impede the truth-seeking function of the court.â€Â  Id.Â  
We think the application of judicial estoppel in a case such as this one would impede the truth-seeking function of the court.Â  McCallâ€™s testimony was necessary in Woodâ€™s trial for purposes unrelated to her case.Â  Estopping the State from later prosecuting McCall would have the effect of unduly limiting the prosecutionâ€™s ability to seek justice.Â  Thus, without reaching the issue of whether judicial estoppel applies in South Carolina in criminal cases, we hold that McCall has failed to make out a case for judicial estoppel.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of McCallâ€™s motion to quash the indictments.
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  See State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 135, 607 S.E.2d 57 (2004).

title: Lanier v. Lanier
description: In this domestic relations case, the court analyzes two issues:  (1) whether the Family Court abused its discretion by failing to set aside a consent judgment under Rule 60(b)(2) on the basis of a prenuptial agreement; and (2) whether the Family Court erred in awarding the husband attorneyâ€™s fees.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Anna H. Lanier, Appellant,
v.
Robert F. Lanier, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3966
Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed March 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald Bruce Clark and Mary Ann Hall, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Marvin I. Oberman and Paul E. Tinkler, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Anna H. Lanier (Wife) and Robert F. Lanier (Husband) entered into a divorce settlement agreement which the family court incorporated into its final order of divorce.Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of her Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP motion for relief from the final order.Â  We affirm. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife, who had been married since 1984, were divorced in March of 2003.Â  Wife alleges that prior to their marriage, the parties entered into an antenuptial agreement (the agreement) in which Husband released his marital rights in Wifeâ€™s property if they divorced.Â  During the course of the marriage, the agreement was lost.Â  Wife searched for the document when she initiated the proceeding.Â  She checked with Husband, her bank (where the document had been stored), and her financial advisor, but her search was not successful.Â  However, several months after the family court entered its final order, Wife found a copy of the agreement folded in a greeting card in her desk drawer.Â  
The content of the agreement was not pled in the original action for divorce.Â  After she found the agreement, Wife filed a motion for relief from the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  The family court heard the matter and denied the motion.Â  On appeal, Wife argues that the requested relief should have been granted because the agreement qualified as newly discovered evidence.Â  Additionally, she disputes the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, Op. No. 3932 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 31, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 48); Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 603 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981); Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  An appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the trial court.â€  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of her burden to convince this Court the family court committed error.  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
A party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.Â  Perry v. Heirs at Law of Gadsden, 357 S.C. 42, 590 S.E.2d 502 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe decision to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) is within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 151, 591 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 413 S.E.2d 15 (1992)); see also Saro Invs. v. Ocean Holiday Pâ€™ship, 314 S.C. 116, 441 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1994) (noting that Rule 60(b) motions are addressed to the discretion of the court and appellate review is limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion).Â  Review is thus limited to determining whether the family court abused its discretion in granting or denying the motion.Â  Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 18, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004); Bowman at 151, 591 S.E.2d at 656.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Rule 60(b)(2) Motion
Wife argues she is entitled to relief from the judgment under Rule 60(b)(2).Â  We disagree.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Propriety of Attacking a Consent Judgment Through a Rule 60(b) Motion
As a preliminary matter, we address whether a consent judgment may be attacked via a Rule 60(b) motion.Â  Husband argues that consent orders are â€œbinding and conclusive and cannot be attacked by the parties either on direct appeal or in a collateral proceeding.â€Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 310 S.C. 44, 46, 425 S.E.2d 46, 48 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Although this is the general rule, consent judgments are subject to attack in particular circumstances, including for the reasons specified in Rule 60(b).Â  See Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 18 n.3, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 n.3 (2004) (â€œ[E]ven consent judgments are subject to attack under particular circumstances.â€).Â  Indeed, the Johnson court ultimately granted relief under Rule 60(b)(5).Â  Id.; Johnson, 310 S.C. at 47, 425 S.E.2d at 48.Â  Additionally, consent orders could be vacated under the statutory predecessor to Rule 60.Â  See Lord Jeff Knitting Co., Inc. v. Mills, 281 S.C. 374, 376, 315 S.E.2d 377, 378 (Ct. App. 1984) (acknowledging availability of relief but refusing it on other grounds).Â  Therefore, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s decision to consider Wifeâ€™s motion on the merits.Â  Â 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 60(b)(2)
The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure apply in family court when no family court rule provides otherwise.Â  Rule 2, SCRFC.Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, reads:

On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 
(2) newly discovered evidence which by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b);
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 

This rule is substantially the same as the federal rule.Â  See Rule 60, SCRCP, note Â¶ 1; Thynes v. Lloyd, 294 S.C. 152, 363 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 1987).
 C.Â Â Â Â Â  Elements for Obtaining a New Trial Under Rule 60(b)(2)
To obtain a new trial based on newly discovered evidence, a movant must establish that the newly discovered evidence: 

(1) will probably change the result if a new trial is granted; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not have been discovered before the trial; (4) is material to the issue; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.

James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 484 (2nd ed. 1996) (citing Johnston v. Belk-McKnight Co., 188 S.C. 149, 198 S.E. 395; McCabe v. Sloan, 184 S.C. 158, 191 S.E. 905 (1937)); see Lans v. Gateway 2000, Inc., 110 F. Supp. 2d 1 (D.D.C. 2000); Raymond v. Raymond Corp., 938 F.2d 1518 (1st Cir. 1991); Duffy v. Clippinger, 857 F.2d 877 (1st Cir. 1988); Lloyd v. Gill, 406 F.2d 585 (5th Cir. 1969); Johnson v. United States, 32 F.2d 127 (8th Cir. 1929); Kettenbach v. Demoulas, 901 F.Supp 486 (D.Mass. 1995); see also Wright & Miller, 11 Fed. Prac. & Proc. Civ. 2d Â§ 2859 (1995) (noting the standard applied to newly discovered evidence is the same for Rule 59(b) and Rule 60(b)(2), and discussing the elements); 12 Mooreâ€™s Federal Practice Â§ 60.42[2] (Matthew Bender 3rd ed.) (discussing various elements tests for Rule 60(b)(2)).
 D.Â Â Â Â Â  Newly Discovered Evidence 
First, we note that courts have found evidence is not newly discovered evidence for the purposes of Rule 60(b)(2) where the evidence was (1) known to the party at the time of trial, and (2) in the partyâ€™s possession.

 1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Known to the Party at the Time of Trial

In Lans v. Gateway 2000, Inc., 110 F.Supp.2d 1 (D.D.C. 2000), the movant, Lans, made a Rule 60(b)(2) motion based on a â€œClarification-Contractâ€ which he found after trial.Â  Lans knew the document existed prior to trial, but was unable to locate it.Â  The Lans court stated:

Lans even admits that he had knowledge of the Clarification-Contract prior to the Courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Gateway. . . . [T]he Court cannot conceive of why Lans failed to notify the Court of the potential existence of the Clarification-Contract and request more time to search for it. . . . Rule 60(b)(2) was not designed to afford parties the opportunity to revisit choices made in the thick of litigation.Â  Since Lans knew of the Clarification-Contractâ€™s existence, he cannot now claim that it is newly discovered evidence.Â  

Id. at 5.Â  See also Andrews Distrib. Co. v. Oak Square at Gatlinburg, Inc., 757 S.W.2d 663, 667 (Tenn. 1988) (finding that when both parties know an item of evidence existed before trial, but the evidence is simply lost or misplaced, finding it afterward does not transform it into newly discovered evidence), overruled on other grounds by Spence v. Allstate Ins. Co., 883 S.W.2d 586 (Tenn. 1994).Â  
We find the instant case analogous to Lans.Â  Wife was well aware the agreement existed; yet, she did not plead its contents or otherwise inform the court of the documentâ€™s potential application.Â  Instead, she chose to initiate this action and negotiate a property settlement without asserting any potential rights which the agreement might have afforded her.Â  Consequently, the agreement was not newly discovered.

 2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the Possession of the Party

The Lans court addressed whether evidence can be newly discovered when it is in the movantâ€™s possession.Â  The court observed that â€œthe Clarification-Contract was in Lansâ€™s possession, even if he could not recall its physical location.â€Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, the evidence was deemed not newly discovered:

[T]his Court has previously held that evidence â€œin the possession of the party before the judgment was rendered . . . is not newly discovered evidence that affords relief.â€Â  American Cetacean Socâ€™y v. Smart, 673 F.Supp. 1102, 1106 (D.D.C. 1987) (Richey, J.).Â  See Coastal Transfer Co. v. Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., 833 F.2d 208, 211-12 (9th Cir. 1987) (evidence that is somehow in possession of a party at time of trial may not be â€œdiscoveredâ€); see also Longden v. Sunderman, 979 F.2d 1095, 1103 (5th Cir. 1992) (misplaced evidence is not newly discovered evidence); Taylor v. Texgas Corp., 831 F.2d 255, 259 (11th Cir. 1987) (party may not â€œdiscoverâ€ after trial evidence that was within knowledge of employees at time of trial). 

Id.Â  â€œFurthermore,â€ the Lans court noted, the evidence â€œturned up in the possession of [Lansâ€™s] accountant.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the court went on to explain that â€œdocuments in the possession of a partyâ€™s agent, such as an attorney or accountant, are deemed to be in the partyâ€™s possession because the party retains control over the documents.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  See also Longden v. Sunderman, 979 F.2d 1095, 1103 (5th Cir. 1992) (finding presence of the missing document in appellantâ€™s files prior to the hearing alone sufficient to deny the Rule 60(b)(2) motion).Â  
Wife admits that the agreement was in her possession and was ultimately found in her desk drawer.Â  Because she both knew of and possessed the agreement prior to trial, we find this evidence does not constitute newly discovered evidence for the purpose of Rule 60(b)(2).Â  
 E.Â Â Â Â Â  Exercise of Due Diligence
Finally, even if the agreement did constitute newly discovered evidence, the family court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to grant a new trial under Rule 60(b)(2) where: (1) Wife knew of the agreement prior to trial, (2) Wife did not plead the agreement, and (3) the agreement was in Wifeâ€™s possession and control prior to trial, but was only later discovered in a desk drawer. 
Rule 60(b)(2) allows the court to grant a new trial only if the newly discovered evidence could not have been discovered by due diligence prior to trial.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œdue diligenceâ€ as â€œ[t]he diligence reasonably expected from, and ordinarily exercised by, a person who seeks to satisfy a legal requirement or to discharge an obligation.â€Â  Id. at 468 (7th ed. 1999).Â  â€œDiligence looks not to what the litigant actually discovered, but what he or she could have discovered.â€Â  12 Mooreâ€™s Federal Practice Â§ 60.42[5] (Matthew Bender 3rd ed.).Â  
When evidence is misplaced, a party must make a specifically targeted search to find the missing evidence.Â  See Lans, 110 F. Supp. 2d at 6 (â€œ[W]hatever actions [the appellant] took to locate the [evidence] are undermined by the plain fact that [he] knew that the [evidence] existed, regardless of whether he could actually get his hands on it.Â  The Court is unsympathetic to arguments that [he] could not remember where [it] was.â€).Â  Where a litigant could have discovered the new evidence prior to trial, he or she is not entitled to relief under Rule 60(b)(2).Â  Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 21, 594 S.E.2d 478, 484 (2004) (citing Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 591 S.E.2d 654, (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  When a party simply misplaces evidence at home, the court will treat the failure to discover it as a failure to exercise due diligence.Â  Johnson Waste Materials v. Marshall, 611 F.2d 593, 598-99 (5th Cir. 1980).Â  Here, Wife eventually found the agreement in a desk drawer in her home.Â  Cognizant of our standard of review, we are unable to find an abuse of discretion where Wife could have located the agreement by conducting a more thorough search of the desk drawer.Â  
In Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 591 S.E.2d 654, (Ct. App. 2004), this Court held that â€œSouth Carolinaâ€™s strong policy towards finality of judgments trumps a partyâ€™s ability to set aside a judgment where, as here, the party could have discovered the evidence prior to trial.â€Â  Id. at 152, 591 S.E.2d at 657.Â  Similarly, when a party is on notice that evidence exists and settles the case without further inquiry, relief under Rule 60(b) is unavailable.Â  Raby Constr., 358 S.C. at 22-23, 594 S.E.2d at 484.Â  
We recognize that in some out-of-state cases new trials were allowed when lost documents were subsequently found.Â  See Wasem v. Ellens, 4 N.W.2d 850 (S.D. 1942); Misel v. Cottonwood Live Stock & Loan Co., 205 N.W. 663 (S.D. 1925); Zarneke v. Kitzman, 183 N.W. 867 (S.D. 1921); Waite v. Fish, 95 N.W. 928 (S.D. 1903); Askew v. Gaskins, 151 S.E. 539 (Ga. Ct. App. 1930); The Protection Life Ins. Co. v. Dill, 91 Ill. 174 (Ill. 1878); Winfield Bldg. & Loan Assâ€™n v. McMullen, 53 P. 481 (Kan. 1898).Â  However, most of these cases sounded in equity and were decided before the advent of Rule 60(b).Â  Additionally, in all of the cases cited, existence of the lost document was alleged at trial.Â  When the documents were found, the courts held that the original documents themselves were material and not merely cumulative of other evidence as to their contents. Thus, retrials were merited.Â  In contrast, Wife did not allege the existence of the agreement at all and made no attempt to recreate any of its contents before settling the case.Â  
In light of this Stateâ€™s strong policy emphasizing finality of judgments, we hold the family court correctly concluded that Wife is not entitled to relief under Rule 60(b).Â  Because we find the evidence was not newly discovered for Rule 60(b) purposes, and the requisite due diligence was not exercised to find it, we affirm the family courtâ€™s refusal to grant Wife a new trial.
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The family court is authorized by statute to order attorneyâ€™s fees to either party in a divorce action.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-3-120 and -130 (1985); Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is at the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, Op. No. 3920 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 10, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 3 at 57) (citing Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial conditions of the parties; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992); Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, Op. No. 3932 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 31, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 48); Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Our supreme court has identified the following factors for determining a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991); Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001).
Wife requested that â€œ[i]f this Court reverses the family court on Issue I, then it should accordingly reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  Because we affirm the family courtâ€™s denial of Wifeâ€™s Rule 60(b)(2) motion, we concomitantly affirm the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the family court is hereby 
 AFFIRMED. Â 
 BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.
