Pursuant to Rule 803(2), a statement â€œrelating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or conditionâ€ is not excluded by the hearsay rule, regardless whether the declarant is available as a witness.Â  Rule 803(2), SCRE; see also State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 20, 558 S.E.2d 518, 520 (2002) (â€œAn excited utterance is a statement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition.â€).
Both the United States Supreme Court and the South Carolina Supreme Court have declared that excited utterance is a firmly rooted hearsay exception.Â  White v. Illinios, 502 U.S. 346, 355 n.8 (â€œThere can be no doubt that the two exceptions we consider in this case are â€˜firmly rooted.â€™Â  The exception for spontaneous declarations is at least two centuries old . . . .Â  It is currently recognized under Federal Rule of Evidence 803(2), and in nearly four-fifths of the States.â€); State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 45, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999) (â€œWe . . . find that the excited utterance exception is firmly rooted in South Carolina law and satisfies the requirements of the Confrontation Clause.â€); accord State v. Dennis 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999).Â  Accordingly, we must determine whether Hillâ€™s statements qualify under the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.Â  If so, they were properly admitted.Â  
Three elements must be met to show a statement is an excited utterance: (1) the statement must relate to a startling event or condition; (2) the statement must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of the excitement; and (3) the stress must have been caused by the startling event or condition.Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  The court must consider the totality of the circumstances in determining whether a statement falls within the excited utterance exception.Â  State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 160, 553 S.E.2d 464, 468 (Ct. App. 2001); State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 S.E.2d 30 (2001).Â  â€œThe rationale behind the excited utterance exception is that the startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication.â€Â  LaCoste at 160, 553 S.E.2d at 468 (quoting State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 284, 523 S.E.2d 173, 177 (1999)).
Time is a factor in the excited utterance analysis, and our courts have allowed intervals in excess of an hour, even up to eleven hours, between the startling event and the statement.Â  See State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 328, 247 S.E.2d 334, 336 (1978).Â  Courts have disallowed use of the excited utterance exception when an unusually long time period passed before the statement was made and the declarant had time to compose himself or herself or had other opportunities to speak.Â  See State v. Whisonant, 335 S.C. 148, 515 S.E.2d 768 (Ct. App. 1999) (rejecting use of the exception based on ten-hour interval and two intervening opportunities to speak in which the declarant said nothing); Burroughs, 328 S.C. at 500-01, 492 S.E.2d at 413-14 (finding no excited utterance when there was a ten-hour interval and the declarant said she used the time to compose herself).Â  The Burroughs court noted a useful rule of thumb that when enough time has elapsed between the event and the statement to permit reflective thought, the statement should be excluded.Â  Id. at 500, 492 S.E.2d at 413.Â  Use of the exception has been overturned when the interval cannot be determined from the record.Â  State v. Garcia, 334 S.C. 71, 77, 512 S.E.2d 507, 510 (1999); State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 501 S.E.2d 122 (1998). 
However, the stress of the eventâ€”not the time between the event and the statementâ€”is the linchpin of the excited utterance exception.Â  See State v. Quillien, 263 S.C. 87, 97, 207 S.E.2d 814, 817 (1974).Â  â€œThere are no hard and fast rules as to when res gestae ends.â€Â  State v. Harrison, 298 S.C. 333, 336, 380 S.E.2d 818, 820 (1989), superseded by rule as stated in Hill, 331 S.C. at 99, 501 S.E.2d at 125.[1]Â  Time is one factor to consider; â€œ[o]ther factors useful in determining whether a statement qualifies as an excited utterance include the declarantâ€™s demeanor, the declarantâ€™s age, and the severity of the startling event.â€Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 22, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  
Additionally, the statement must be based on firsthand information, such as statements of an actual witness to an event.Â  Hill, 331 S.C. at 99, 501 S.E.2d at 125; LaCoste, 347 S.C. at 161, 553 S.E.2d at 468.Â  Firsthand knowledge may be established by information conveyed in the statement itself.Â  Id. at 161, 553 S.E.2d at 469.Â  

  3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Application of Excited Utterance Exception to Hillâ€™s Statement

Hillâ€™s statement that the shotgun was used to kill Davis relates to a murder, and murder is certainly a startling event.Â  See State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 284, 523 S.E.2d 173, 177 (1999) (rejecting appellantâ€™s argument that the State failed to show a statement was an excited utterance where declarant had just seen his brother shoot an unarmed man, abruptly ending a fistfight).Â  The closer issue is whether Hill was under the stress of the startling event when he made the controverted statements.Â  
Considering the factors of severity of the stress of the event, time between the event and the utterance, and surrounding indicia of stress, we find sufficient evidence that Hill was under the stress of the murder when he made the declarations to Hicks.Â  The statements relate to a highly stressful event.Â  The time between the event and the statements was well within the time frame courts have allowed for excited utterances.Â  See, e.g., Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 515 S.E.2d 525 (allowing statements made less than one hour after event).Â  Here, Hill encountered Hicks just ten to thirty minutes after Stevens and the two unidentified individuals fled from the murder scene.Â  Furthermore, surrounding circumstances point to a conclusion that the stress of the event had not abated.Â  Both Davis and Stevens bought an unusually large amount of drugs; Davis was willing to exchange an entire bag full of coins for drugs without counting it; and Stevens gave away drugs in an unusually generous gesture.Â  
Furthermore, we find the record strongly supports Hillâ€™s statements were based on firsthand information.Â  Hill established that â€œ[s]tatements which are not based on firsthand information, as where the declarant was not an actual witness to the event, are not admissible under the exited utterance . . . exception to the hearsay rule.â€Â  331 S.C. at 99, 501 S.E.2d at 125 (citing 23 C.J.S. Crim. Law Â§ 876 (1989)).Â  In Hill, the defendant shot a police officer in a car wash parking lot.Â  Kenneth Grant arrived at the car wash fifteen minutes after the shooting, and testified in camera that some fifteen to twenty minutes after arriving he heard an unidentifiable person in the crowd say there were two suspects.Â  The supreme court agreed with the trial court that the hearsay was inadmissible.Â  Among other reasons for the ruling, there was â€œno evidence the unidentified declarant witnessed the shooting.â€Â  Id. at 100, 501 S.E.2d at 125.Â  Subsequently, LaCoste amplified Hill by holding that firsthand knowledge of unknown declarants may be established by the declaration itself.Â  347 S.C. at 161, 553 S.E.2d at 469.Â  
Here, there is sufficient evidence that Hillâ€™s declarations to Hicks were based on personal knowledge.Â  Unlike State v. Hill, the declarant in this case was known.Â  Immediately before the shooting, Steven and Davis were heard arguing with the victim.Â  Just after the shooting three individuals, one of whom was Stevens, were seen fleeing the scene.Â  Minutes later Hill appeared with Stevens and Davis.Â  We find this evidence supports the inference that Hill was one of the three individuals fleeing the scene; that he was, therefore, present at the murder scene; and that he had firsthand knowledge that the shotgun had been used to kill Williams.Â  
Bolstering this conclusion is a â€œjailhouse confession,â€ signed by Davis, indicating that Davis shot the victim.Â  When Davis was arrested, he was jailed and placed in a cell directly across from Hicks, who was incarcerated on an unrelated offense.Â  According to Hicks, he and Davis would communicate with each other by placing a letter in a book and sliding the book from cell to cell.Â  Hicks stated that he slid the following letter, which was admitted into evidence, to Davis:

  Hey Chris the night that yaâ€™ll came and tried to sell me the shotgun was yaâ€™ll coming from Paulâ€™s house then what I need to know from you who was the trigger man and I know it wasnâ€™t Greg from what he told me that night so it had to be [illegible] you or Reggie cause you had the gun and Greg told me you and Reggie the who [sic] went in the house so who pulled the triggerÂ Â  if Reggie did it just write Reggieâ€™s name or if you did just sign your name at the bottom and I will help you out by writing that letter just write what you want me to tell them.

The letter is signed â€œChristopher Davisâ€ and dated â€œ3-15-01.â€Â  A handwriting expert testified that the signature was Davisâ€™s.Â  Hicks acknowledged that he observed Davis sign the letter, and Davis admitting signing a piece of paper for Hicks, although he contended it was blank when he signed it.Â  Davis does not appeal the trial judgeâ€™s admission of this confession.Â  Therefore, its stands on its own and was independent evidence for the juryâ€™s consideration.Â  The confession indicates that Hicks knew from Hill that either Stevens or Davis shot the victim.Â  Thus, the confession, coupled with the strong inference that Hill was present at the crime scene, constitutes sufficient evidence that Hill had personal knowledge of the contents of his declarations.Â Â  
Based on the totality of the circumstance, we find the record supports (1) Hillâ€™s statement was related to a startling event; (2) it was made while Hill was under the stress of the event; (3) the stress resulted from the startling event; and (4) the statement was based on firsthand information.Â  We therefore find Hillâ€™s statement admissible under Rule 803(2), a firmly rooted hearsay exception.Â  
II.Â  Harmless Error
Finally, the State contends any error in admission of Hillâ€™s hearsay declarations would be harmless.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œA violation of the defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront the witness is not per se reversible error if the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 454, 602 S.E.2d 62, 73 (Ct. App. 2004) (internal quotation marks omitted) (quoting State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 333, 563 S.E.2d 315, 318 (2002)); see also Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673 (1986) (finding Confrontation Clause violations are subject to harmless error analysis); Bockting v. Bayer, ___ F.3d ___, 2005 WL 406284 *8 (9th Cir. 2005) (â€œConfrontation Clause violations are subject to harmless error analysis and thus may be excused depending on the state of the evidence at trial.â€); United States v. Nielsen, 371 F.3d 574, 581 (9th Cir. 2004) (â€œConfrontation Clause violations are subject to harmless error analysis, because the Constitution entitles a criminal defendant to a fair trial, not a perfect one.â€) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted); Smith v. State, ___ So.2d ___, 2004 WL 921748 (Ala. Crim. App. 2004) (noting Confrontation Clause violations are subject to harmless error analysis); State v. Cotto, 865 A.2d 660 (N.J. 2005) (holding statements which did not fall under excited utterance exception were erroneously admitted but that the error was harmless); State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 386, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994) (â€œA violation of the defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront the witness is not per se reversible error.Â  This Court must determine whether the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.â€) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted); State v. Portnoy, 718 P.2d 805 (Wash. Ct. App. 1986) (finding Confrontation Clause violations are subject to harmless error analysis); cf. Neder v. United States, 527 U.S. 1 (1999) (noting the erroneous admission of evidence in violation of the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s guarantee against self-incrimination, and the erroneous exclusion of evidence in violation of the right to confront witnesses guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment are both subject to harmless error analysis). 
Courts around the nation have found that Crawford violations are no exception to this rule.Â  United States v. Rodriguez-Marrero, 390 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2004) (finding signed confession testimonial under Crawford and engaging in a sua sponte harmless error analysis, but concluding admission of the statements was not harmless); United States v. McClain, 377 F.3d 219 (2nd Cir. 2004) (â€œIt is well established that violations of the Confrontation Clause, if preserved for appellate review, are subject to harmless error review . . . and Crawford does not suggest otherwise.â€) (citations omitted); United States v. Rashid, 383 F.3d 769 (8th Cir. 2004) (noting statements taken by FBI agent during course of interrogation were testimonial for purposes of Crawford, but admission was harmless error because other evidence of guilt was overwhelming); Stancil v. United States, ___ A.2d ___, ___, 2005 WL 195547 at *13 (D.C. Cir. 2005) (observing that the harmless error analysis applies to Crawford violations but finding the government had not made a sufficient showing the error was harmless); People v. Song, 22 Cal.Rptr.3d 118 (Cal. App. 2004) (employing harmless error analysis to Crawford violation and finding admission of the testimonial evidence was not harmless error); People v. Edwards, 101 P.3d 1118 (Colo. App. 2004) (â€œ[V]iolations of the rule announced in Crawford constitute errors in the trial process and are subject to either plain or harmless error review.â€); Bell v. State, 597 S.E.2d 350 (Ga. 2004) (finding statements victim made to police officer were testimonial and inadmissible under Crawford, but that the error was harmless); People v. Patterson, 808 N.E.2d 1159 (2004) (applying harmless error analysis to alleged Crawford violation); Hammon v. State, 809 N.E.2d 945 (Ind. App. 2004) (opining that even if battery affidavit were testimonial and improperly admitted, any error was harmless because its content was cumulative of other evidence); State v. Wright, 686 N.W.2d 295 (Minn. App. 2004) (declining to rule whether a 911 call was testimonial because even if it were, admission of the call would constitute harmless error).
Whether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (1998); State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 575 S.E.2d 77 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  No definite rule of law governs this finding.Â  State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985).
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. at 63, 584 S.E.2d at 897; Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Where a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996); Thompson, 352 S.C. at 562, 575 S.E.2d at 83; State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the verdict obtained.Â  Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992).
Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795; see also State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) (noting that when guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached, this Court will not set aside the conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result).Â  
The admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.Â  State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003); State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 247 S.E.2d 334 (1978); State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 469 S.E.2d 49 (1996) (instructing that error in admission of evidence is harmless where it is cumulative to other evidence which was properly admitted); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (explicating that any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).
Hillâ€™s statements, as related by Hicks, were (1) Davis and Stevens went into the victimâ€™s house, and (2) the shotgun that Davis was trying to sell was used to murder the victim.Â  Considering the other evidence before the jury, we harbor no reasonable doubts that any error in admitting Hillâ€™s statement would have been harmless.Â Â  
Foremost, Davisâ€™s confession, the admission of which is not at issue, contains the substance of Hillâ€™s statements as testified to by Hicks.Â  The confession establishes that Hicks knew â€œfrom what Greg [Hill] told me that night . . . [the trigger man] had to be . . . you or Reggie [Stevens] cause you had the gun and Greg told me you and Reggie the who [sic] went in the house . . . .â€Â  Thus, the substance of Hillâ€™s declarations were properly before the jury.Â  Consequently, Hicksâ€™s testimony as to Hillâ€™s hearsay was merely cumulative of other evidence, and its admissionâ€”even if erroneousâ€”was harmless.Â  
Additionally, two witnesses, Hicks and his brother, Raymond, heard Davis, Stevens, and the victim arguing just before the gunshot.Â  Following the gunshot, Hicks, Raymond, and a third witness, Calvin Patten, observed three individuals running from the victimâ€™s back yard.Â  Hicks and Patten both identified Stevens as one of the fleeing men, and police matched Stevensâ€™s shoeprint with one found at the crime scene.Â  
Between ten and thirty minutes after the gunshot, Hill, Stevens, and Davis were seen together.Â  According to Hicks, Davis had the shotgun, and Stevens purchased over $100 worth of crack cocaine, an unusually large purchase for Stevens.Â  Calvin Patten testified that Stevens gave him some drugs in an uncharacteristically generous gesture.Â  Lorenzo White averred that late one night Davis came to his house with the shotgun, wiped it down with Clorox to remove finger prints, and hid the gun somewhere in Whiteâ€™s house.Â  
Thus, excluding Hicksâ€™s testimony regarding Hillâ€™s hearsay statements, the jury heard evidence that several witnesses overheard Stevens, Davis, and Williams arguing; thereafter a gun was fired; Stevens and two other individuals were seen fleeing the crime scene; Stevensâ€™s footprint was found at the crime scene; Stevens and Hill emerged and made a large drug purchase; Stevens gave away some crack cocaine in an unusually generous gesture; minutes later, Stevens and Hill returned with Davis, who was trying to sell a shotgun; Davis took the shotgun to a friends house, where he wiped down the gun with Clorox and hid it; Hicks wrote that he knew Davis and Stevens entered the house, and that one of them shot the victim; and Davis confessed to the murder.Â  Under these facts, even were we to conclude Hillâ€™s statements were improperly admitted, they were cumulative of statements in the confession, and the other evidence against Davis was so substantial that the hearsay utterances were neither material nor prejudicial.Â  Therefore, any error in admitting the statements would be harmless.Â  
CONCLUSION

Hillâ€™s hearsay statements to Hicks were properly admitted.Â  The utterances were nontestimonial; therefore, Crawford v. Washington does not bar the admission of these statements, even though Hill was unavailable at trial and Davis did not have a prior opportunity to cross-examine him.Â  Hillâ€™s statements were admissible under the excited utterance exception, Rule 803(2), SCRE, which is recognized as a firmly rooted hearsay exception.Â  Accordingly, the Confrontation Clause does not require that Davis have the opportunity to cross-examine Hill regarding the nontestimonial excited utterance.Â  Regardless, any error in admitting the statements would have been harmless.Â  Davisâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Although Harrison, Blackburn, and Quillien predate the South Carolina Rule of Evidence, their reasoning is still efficacious.Â  Those cases were decided under the res gestae doctrine, and Rules 803(1) & (2) codify res gestae.Â  See State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 43, 515 S.E.2d 525, 530 (1999); State v. Burroughs, 328 S.C. 489, 498-99, 492 S.E.2d 408, 412-14 (Ct. App. 1997).Â

title: State v. Wallace
description: Karl Wallace was convicted of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.  He argues the trial court erred by admitting the testimony of the victim's sister regarding an alleged prior act of criminal sexual conduct with a minor under the common plan or scheme exception to State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), and Rule 404(b), SCRE.  We reverse and remand for a new trial, finding an insufficient connection between the crime charged and the prior bad act.  Further, we found the trial court erred in redacting the sister's testimony to make it more similar to the crime charged.
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Karl Wallace, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3971
Heard November 17, 2004 â€“ Filed March 28, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, and Everett P. Godfrey, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Karl Wallace was convicted of second-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor.Â  He argues the trial court erred by admitting the testimony of the victimâ€™s sister regarding an alleged prior act of criminal sexual conduct with a minor under the common scheme or plan exception to State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), and Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTS

Wallace was accused of criminal sexual conduct with his stepdaughter.Â  At the time of trial, Wallace had been married to the victimâ€™s mother for approximately ten years.Â  At trial, the victim testified she was about twelve years old when Wallace first told her to come to his room and go into the bathroom to take off all of her clothes.Â  She said he would look at her and then touch her on her chest.Â  After he touched her, he would tell her â€œdonâ€™t tell anyone â€˜cause theyâ€™re not going to believe you anyway.â€Â  When asked how many times this happened, the victim answered â€œonce, like every other month or so one time.â€Â  This pattern continued through the seventh and eighth grades.Â  
Although the incidents allegedly continued over a number of years, this charge involved an act on May 8, 2001, when the victim was in the ninth grade.Â  According to the victim, Wallace called the victim into his bedroom to talk after her mother had been taken into police custody on an unrelated matter.Â  After asking the victim why she was sitting with her legs closed and whether she thought he was going to do something to her, Wallace pushed her back on the bed.Â  The victim stated that Wallace â€œsat on top of me and like between my legs and we were just sitting there.â€Â  Wallace asked her, â€œdo you want me to be myself or be like a dog,â€ to which she responded, â€œto be hisself [sic].â€Â  Wallace then removed her pajama bottoms and her underwear, forced open her legs, and started â€œto push his hands up [her] privates.â€Â  As he continued, the victim started to scream.Â  Wallace put a pillow over her face and told her to be quiet or he would hit her.Â  She testified that when Wallace heard her little brother coming down the hall, he told her to go into the bathroom and get dressed.Â  After her brother left the room, Wallace forced her back on the bed, got on top of her, and took her pants off again.Â  After sitting and looking at her, he told her to go get her things and leave.Â  
A few days later, the victimâ€™s older sister came to the school to see the victim and to find out what was going on at home.Â  The victim told her sister that Wallace had been â€œmessing withâ€ her.Â  As a result of that conversation, someone from the Department of Social Services visited the victim at school.Â  The victim subsequently filed a police report.Â  Â 
At trial, the State attempted to present evidence of an alleged sexual assault against the sister as proof of Wallaceâ€™s guilt.Â  Prior to the start of trial, the State moved to allow the testimony of the sister, proffering the following argument:

  Itâ€™s the Stateâ€™s position that her testimony would be that she was also sexually abused by this defendant that [sic] the abuse started at approximately the same age with both of the victims, that being the seventh grade, roughly, for both of them, between twelve and thirteen years old; that they were both the defendantâ€™s stepdaughters; that they were both living in the home with the defendant, as opposed to visiting on weekends and the abuse happening then; that the method of the abuse essentially started the same way, it started with fondling of the breasts, is [sic] where it began; and that it would occur in the home, . . . it occurred in the bedroom; and it occurred when the mother was not home, . . . .

The State concluded by stating that the sister suffered more extensive abuse.Â  Specifically, she was subjected to sexual intercourse and oral sex.Â  The State asserted it â€œwould be willing to offer to limit testimony, if you see fit, as to just the particulars that were similar.â€Â  When questioned by the trial court, the State said the sister specifically did not want to bring charges against Wallace.Â  Defense counsel argued the testimony of the sister, as to the alleged prior bad act, did not fit any exception to Lyle and would be grossly prejudicial to Wallace.
The trial court ordered an in camera examination of the sister.Â  She testified that when she was in the sixth or seventh grade Wallace would come into her room to rub her back because he was trying to get her to lose weight.Â  He then would touch her breasts, kiss her, and perform oral sex.Â  When she was in the eighth grade, the family moved from Louisiana to South Carolina.Â  The sister testified Wallace would call her into his bedroom and perform oral sex, digital penetration, and sexual intercourse.Â  She testified she told her mother about the incidents on two separate occasions.Â  Â The sister testified the sexual assaults continued until she moved out of the family home during her second semester in college.Â  
After hearing the testimony and arguments, the trial court found the testimony to be clear and convincing and ruled this evidence was admissible under the common scheme or plan exception to Lyle.Â  Concluding the probative value outweighed the prejudicial effect, the trial court allowed the evidence to be presented to the jury but limited the testimony of the sister â€œonly to the extent and only to the acts which occurred to the victim in this prosecution, and not to go beyond that, which will limit the prejudicial effect of this testimony coming in.â€Â  A jury found Wallace guilty of second-degree CSC with a minor, and he was sentenced to eight years confinement.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

On review of criminal cases, an appellate court is limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  See State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the circuit court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 489-90, 589 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œConcerning the admission of evidence, the trial judgeâ€™s determination will be sustained absent error and resulting prejudice.â€Â  State v. Robinson, 360 S.C. 187, 192, 600 S.E.2d 100, 102 (Ct. App. 2004) (citation omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS

 
Wallace argues the trial court improperly admitted the testimony of the victimâ€™s sister as to alleged criminal sexual assaults under the common scheme or plan exception of Rule 404(b), SCRE and State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  We agree. 
Evidence of prior bad acts is inadmissible to prove the specific crime charged unless the evidence tends to establish (1) motive; (2) intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other that proof of one tends to establish proof of the other; or (5) identity of the person charged with the present crime. Lyle, 125 S.C. at 416, 118 S.E. at 807; Rule 404(b), SCRE (â€œEvidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.â€). 
A prior bad act must first be established by clear and convincing evidence to be admissible. State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 325, 580 S.E.2d 186, 189 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  When considering whether there is clear and convincing evidence, this court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 325, 580 S.E.2d at 189; State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 468, 523 S.E.2d 787, 791 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating if a prior bad act is not the subject of a conviction, proof must be by clear and convincing evidence).Â  
Here, Wallace does not argue the quantum of proof did not rise to the clear and convincing level.Â  Instead, he argues the trial judge misapprehended the nature of the common scheme or plan exception as articulated in Lyle.Â  Wallace urges us to review the underlying facts of Lyle in order to fully understand the common scheme or plan exception.Â  
In Lyle, the defendant was charged with issuing a forged check in Aiken, South Carolina on January 12, 1922.Â  125 S.C. at 411, 118 S.E. at 805.Â  The State introduced evidence that the defendant had committed similar crimes in Aiken on that same date, as well as similar crimes in Griffin, Georgia on January 3, 1922; Athens, Georgia on December 30, 1921; and LaGrange, Georgia on November 23, 1921.Â  Id. at 413-14, 118 S.E. at 806.Â  The allegation was the same in all the crimes:Â  the defendant entered the bank, opened an account with a forged check using a false name, and received cash back from his deposit.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court held that the evidence regarding the similar crime committed in Aiken on the same date as the crime charged was admissible to establish identity because the evidence helped to refute the alibi defense of the defendant.Â  Id. at 418, 118 S.E. at 808.Â  As to the similar crimes committed on other dates in other locations, however, the Supreme Court found the evidence inadmissible.Â  The court stated:

  Whether such crime was committed as part of a common plan or system was wholly immaterial, unless proof of such system would serve to identify the defendant as the perpetrator of the particular crime charged or was necessary to establish the element of criminal intent.Â  Proof of a common plan or system, therefore, in this connection is merely an evidential means to the end of proving identity or guilty intent, and involves the establishment of such a visible connection between the extraneous crimes and the crime charged as will make evidence of one logically tend to prove the other as charged.Â  If, as we have seen, no such connection was shown to exist between the separate Georgia offenses and the Aiken crime as would constitute them practically â€œa continuous transactionâ€ or as would otherwise render this evidence relevant to prove identity, and if, as we have held, the evidence was not competent on the question of intent, it follows that it was not admissible merely to show plan or system.

Id. at 427, 118 S.E. at 811 (emphasis added) (citations omitted). This notion of the connection which must be established between similar crimes in order to allow admission of evidence of one of the crimes in the trial of the other had been previously articulated in two New York cases, People v. Molineux, 61 N.E. 286 (N.Y. 1901) and People v. Romano, 82 N.Y.S. 749 (N.Y. App. Div. 1903), relied on by the court in Lyle.Â  
In Molineux, the defendant was accused of murder by sending poison contained in a bottle of Bromo Seltzer[1] through the mail to the director of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.Â  61 N.E. at 287.Â  The director, Harry Cornish, believing the silver â€œTiffanyâ€™sâ€ bottle holder containing the bottle of Bromo Seltzer to be a Christmas gift, took it to his home.Â  Thereafter, a member of his household, Katharine Adams, took some of the bottleâ€™s contents to relieve a headache and died.Â  At trial, the State sought to introduce into evidence that the defendant was responsible for the previous death of Henry Barnet, who died at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club after taking a dose of a powder he had received in the mail the month before Cornish received his bottle.Â  Id. at 289.Â  Both powders were in fact cyanide of mercury, a rare and deadly poison.Â  The evidence of the prior crime was admitted in the trial court.Â  The Court of Appeals of New York reversed, and in a very thorough-going opinion, clearly articulated the limited nature of the common scheme or plan exception to the general rule which proscribes the admission of evidence of other crimes to prove the crime charged.Â  The New York Court stated:

  It sometimes happens that two or more crimes are committed by the same person in pursuance of a single design, or under circumstances which render it impossible to prove one without proving all.Â  To bring a case within this exception to the general rule which excludes proof of extraneous crimes, there must be evidence of system between the offense on trial and the one sought to be introduced.Â  They must be connected as parts of a general and composite plan or scheme, or they must be so related to each other as to show a common motive or intent running through both. 

Id. at 299.
In Romano, the defendant was charged with robbing his victim by throwing snuff into his face.Â  82 N.Y.S. at 749.Â  At trial, the State sought to introduce evidence that the defendant had committed another robbery at the same location upon another person by using the same method.Â  Although the trial court admitted the evidence finding the two crimes remarkably similar, the appellate court reversed.Â  The New York Court of Appeals stated:Â  

  There is always more or less of similarity between the commission of independent crimes of this class, and in many instances features that are common to one are found in the other; and yet it has never been supposed that, where there was separation as to time and no connection established beyond that of place and similarity, the first crime was admissible to establish any of the elements which constituted the other.

Id. at 750.Â  
Wallace argues that in admitting the sisterâ€™s testimony, the trial judge impermissibly broadened the meaning of the common scheme or plan exception enunciated in Lyle, to include mere similar acts.Â  According to Wallace, the trial judge erroneously assumed that a broader application of the exception was warranted because this case involved criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  However, the appellate courts of this state have refused to recognize a specific exception to the inadmissibility of prior bad act evidence in criminal sexual conduct cases.Â  See State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 14 n.16, 501 S.E.2d 716, 723 n.16 (1998) (ruling that evidence of defendant's general pedophile characteristics was inadmissible, and noting that â€œ[i]n spite of the ban on character or propensity evidence, some states have nonetheless admitted evidence of collateral sexual crimes or sexual bad acts in sex offense cases, carving out a specific exception they variously term â€˜lustful disposition,â€™ â€˜depraved sexual instinct,â€™ or the like. . . .Â  South Carolina has not recognized such an exception, nor are we inclined to do so.â€); Tutton, 354 S.C. at 328, 580 S.E.2d at 191 (finding the bar for admissibility under Lyle is not lower simply because sexual crimes are involved; there must still be â€œevidence that the defendant employed a common scheme or plan in the commission of the crimesâ€).[2]Â  
 In this case, the trial court did not address any connection between the two crimes to establish if the allegations by the victimâ€™s sister were admissible.Â  The court instead ruled, â€œit goes to a common scheme or plan because of the close degree of similarity between the conduct, with regards to the two victims.â€Â  When the State was asked to explain why the testimony was essential to its case, the solicitor responded:

  This is technically a credibility case, thatâ€™s what it is.Â  Itâ€™s one witnessâ€™s word against potentially another witnessâ€™s word.Â  The evidence would be relevant and would be essential to the Stateâ€™s case because it is a piece of evidence, just like any other piece of evidence, that goes to prove or disprove the case.Â  And this is strictly a credibility case:Â  Therefore, this testimony is necessary to, again, prove the victimâ€™s allegations.Â Â  

This argument could be used to admit testimony of any prior crime when a defendant is accused of a subsequent but similar crime.Â  It falls far short of the threshold for the admission of a prior crime under the common scheme or plan exception to Lyle.Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred in admitting the evidence on this basis.
It was also error for the trial judge to attempt to limit the testimony of the sister so that there would be a close similarity between the prior bad act and the crime charged.Â Â  The court noted that the testimony of the sister was more egregious than that of the victim and ordered the testimony redacted, stating, â€œI find it appropriate under State v. Tutton to limit the testimony of the Lyle witness only to the extent and only to the acts which occurred to the victim in this prosecution, and not to go beyond that, which will limit the prejudicial effect of this testimony coming in.â€Â  This court in Tutton concluded the differences in the evidence proffered of the prior criminal sexual conduct was sufficiently different to render it inadmissible.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 333, 580 S.E.2d at 194. We did not, however, sanction the redaction of testimony in order to make similar that which is dissimilar. 
Wallace correctly argues: â€œThe law should not permit a trial judge to make similar that which is different by redacting a part of the testimony.â€Â  This is precisely what Lyle rejected.Â  Moreover, as noted in Lyle, â€œif the court does not clearly perceive the connection between the extraneous criminal transaction and the crime charged, that is, its logical relevancy, the accused should be given the benefit of the doubt, and the evidence should be rejected.â€Â  125 S.C. at 417, 118 S.E.2d at 807.Â Â  Thus, the trial court erred in endeavoring to eliminate any differences between the sisterâ€™s account and the victimâ€™s testimony in order to make the sisterâ€™s testimony admissible.Â  See Hubner, Op. No. 3917 (Ct. App. filed Jan. 10, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 2 at 79) (concluding the trial court erred in limiting the testimony regarding prior bad acts to similar acts when the court recognized the differences between prior bad act and the act at issue but failed to balance the similarities and differences in determining whether the testimony was admissible at all).Â Â  Rather, the trial judge should have given Wallace the benefit of the doubt and excluded the evidence.Â  See Stokes, 279 S.C. at 193, 304 S.E.2d at 815 (â€œIf there is any doubt as to the connection between the acts, the evidence should not be admitted.â€); State v. Davenport, 321 S.C. 134, 138, 467 S.E.2d 258, 260 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding that where there was no clear connection between the extraneous criminal transaction and the crime charged, the accused should have been given the benefit of the doubt, and the evidence should have been rejected). 
In addition to finding the admission of the sisterâ€™s testimony error, we find the admission was not harmless.Â  As in Hubner, the outcome of this case rested on the credibility of the victim and Wallace.Â  Op. No. 3917 (Ct. App. filed Jan. 10, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 2 at 92).Â  Here, the admission of the sisterâ€™s testimony enhanced the credibility of the victim and was provided as substantive prove of the victimâ€™s allegations.Â  Without the sisterâ€™s testimony, we cannot say that the evidence against Wallace was conclusively established such that a guilty verdict was the only rational result.Â  See Tutton, 354 S.C. at 334, 580 S.E.2d at 194 (stating that in conducting an harmless analysis, the appellate court must review the other evidence admitted at trial in order to determine â€œwhether the defendantâ€™s guilt is conclusively established by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion could be reached by the juryâ€). 
CONCLUSION

Accordingly, we reverse Wallaceâ€™s conviction and remand for a new trial.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] Bromo Seltzer is a brand of drug used to treat stomach upset and headache.Â  See http://www.drugs.com/cons/Bromo_Seltzer.html (last visited Feb. 11, 2005).
[2] Wallace argues that numerous opinions from both this court and the South Carolina Supreme Court have focused exclusively on the close degree of similarity between the crime charged and the evidence of the other crime, without mentioning the â€œsystemâ€ or relation between the two, which is the crux of the original exception.Â  See, e.g., State v. Hallman, 298 S.C. 172, 175, 379 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1989) (â€œWe find the evidence of prior bad acts bears such close similarity to the offense charged in this case that its probative value clearly outweighs its prejudicial effect.â€); State v. McClellan, 283 S.C. 389, 392, 323 S.E.2d 772, 774 (1984) (â€œSuch evidence is inadmissible â€˜unless the close similarity of the charged offense and the previous act enhances the probative value of the evidence so as to overrule the prejudicial effect.â€™â€); State v. Patrick, 318 S.C. 352, 356 457 S.E.2d 632, 635 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œThere are sufficient similarities between the Georgia case and present case to apply the Lyle common scheme or plan exception.â€); State v. Blanton, 316 S.C. 31, 32, 446 S.E.2d 438, 439 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œThe prior acts were sufficiently similar to the charged offense to be admissible.â€); State v. Wingo, 304 S.C. 173, 176, 403 S.E.2d 322, 324 (Ct. App. 1991) (finding the evidence of prior bad acts tended to show common plan or scheme when the experiences of each victim paralleled that of the other victims). 
According to Wallace, other decisions correctly reflect a more narrow interpretation of the common scheme or plan exception.Â  See, e.g., State v. Brooks, 341 S.C. 57, 62, 533 S.E.2d 325, 328 (2000) (â€œWhen the prior bad acts are similar to the one for which the appellant is being tried, the danger of prejudice is enhanced.â€); State v. Parker, 315 S.C. 230, 233, 433 S.E.2d 831, 832 (1993) (â€œ[T]he connection between the prior bad act and the crime must be more than just a general similarity.â€); State v. Rogers, 293 S.C. 505, 507, 362 S.E.2d 7, 8 (1987) (stating that where the acts are ten years apart and the only connection between the testimony of the two daughters was that the defendant touched them both, the prior bad act evidence should have been excluded), overruled on other grounds by State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 506 n.1, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 n.1 (1993); State v. Nix, 288 S.C. 492, 496, 343 S.E.2d 627, 629 (1986) (finding where the robbery could not have been committed without the get-away-car, the relevance of the car theft to the crimes charged was easily perceived); State v. Stokes, 279 S.C. 191, 192-93, 304 S.E.2d 814, 814-15 (1983) (concluding the trial judge erred in admitting testimony from a witness who speculated that the defendant intended to rape her because there was no connection made between that prior bad act and the act for which the defendant was charged); State v. Whitener, 228 S.C. 244, 265, 89 S.E.2d 701, 711 (1955) (allowing testimony of another sexual act perpetrated against the same victim some hours after the original offense because the crimes were so related to each other that proof of one tended to establish the other); State v. Hubner, Op. No. 3917 (Ct. App. filed Jan. 10, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 2 at 89) (stating that the similarity between separate acts must not merely be a similarity in the results; â€œ[r]ather, there must be such a concurrence of common features that the various acts are normally to be explained as caused by a general plan of which they are the individual manifestationsâ€); State v. Carter, 323 S.C. 465, 468, 476 S.E.2d 916, 918 (Ct. App. 1996) (reversing defendantâ€™s conviction where there was no legal connection between the prior bad act and the crime charged); State v. Campbell, 317 S.C. 449, 451, 454 S.E.2d 899, 901 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding absent a connection between the two acts, the testimony of prior drug sales utilizing a similar sales technique precisely the type of evidence Lyle prohibits).
Wallace is correct that some of the appellate decisions appear to focus exclusively on the alleged close similarity between the other crime and the crime charged, while others look beyond mere close similarity to consider the system or connection between the two.Â  Nevertheless, sorting out any apparent inconsistencies in the appellate decisions of this state is not the province of this court.Â  See M & T Chems., Inc. v. Barker Indus., Inc., 296 S.C. 103, 109, 370 S.E.2d 886, 890 (Ct. App. 1988) (stating that an intermediate appellate court has no authority to change existing law, but maintaining that the supreme court may want to grant certiorari and modify previous decisions).

title: Peoples v. Henry Company
description: This is an appeal from a workers' compensation award, compensating Samuel K. Peoples for sixty-eight percent permanent partial disability to his right lower extremity.  Henry Company appeals arguing Peoples' injury to his Achilles tendon was an injury to the foot and not the leg.  We affirm, finding sufficient evidence that Peoples suffered an injury to the leg.
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
.style2 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-weight: bold; }
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Samuel K. Peoples, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Henry Company and Zurich American Insurance Co., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3972
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Andrew D. Kaplan, Steven M. Rudisill, of Charlotte, for Appellants.
        David Vance Benson, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Henry Company and its insurer appeal an order of the circuit court finding its employee, Samuel K. Peoples, sustained an injury arising out of and in the course of employment and awarding him compensation for sixty-eight percent permanent partial disability to his right lower extremity.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

Peoples, a forty-three year old man with a high school education, worked for Henry Company for twenty-three years.Â  An accident at work in 1999 resulted in a rupture of his Achilles tendon.Â  He underwent two surgeries and a third one was recommended.Â  Peoples elected not to have the third surgery because the chances of improvement did not appear to be good, and he would likely face a fusion of his ankle bones.Â  
After the surgeries, Peoples returned to work at the same job but endured constant pain.Â  On a scale of one to ten, his pain level was at a six in the morning and at a seven when he returned home at the end of the day.Â  He takes medication, but his leg remains swollen and painful.Â  He now has difficulty walking and standing for long periods of time.Â  Peoples stated that he is unable to participate in sports, cannot lift heavy objects, and climbs stairs with difficulty.Â  Additionally, his ability to rotate his ankle is impaired and his lateral movement has been reduced by seventy percent.Â  
The pain in Peoplesâ€™ right leg generally radiates to just below the knee.Â  He has a scar on the back of his leg about eight inches long running from his heel toward his knee.Â  He must wear protective shoes to work every day.Â  Peoples further testified that he has pain from his heel to his lower back from time to time, and that he takes Ultracet to control the pain.Â  
The single commissioner held that Peoples had undergone a sixty-eight percent permanent partial disability to his right lower extremity and awarded benefits accordingly.Â  The commissioner also ordered Henry Company to provide orthopedic footwear for life and to continue to provide Peoples with Ultracet or some equivalent medication for the pain.Â  
Henry Company appealed to the full commission.Â  The commission affirmed, except that it reduced the level of disability to forty percent.Â  
Both parties appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court found that the decision of the full commission to reduce the level of disability to forty percent was without evidentiary support.Â  The circuit court therefore reinstated the award of sixty-eight percent disability by the single commissioner.Â  Henry Company argued on appeal that Peoplesâ€™ injury was to his foot only, not his leg.Â  Finding the Achilles tendon to be a part of the leg, the circuit court affirmed the remainder of the commissionâ€™s order.Â  
Henry Company has appealed, arguing the circuit court erred in (1) sustaining the finding of partial disability to his leg instead of only his foot, and (2) finding that Peoples needed Ultracet to control the pain.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

Judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency is governed by the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-310 to -400 (Supp. 2004).Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(6) establishes the substantial evidence rule as the standard of review.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)(6)(d) and (e).Â  
Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Stephens v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Instead, review of issues of fact is limited to determining whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports its findings.â€Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Henry Company first argues the circuit court erred in affirming the commissionâ€™s award for disability to Peoplesâ€™ right leg instead of only his right foot.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œWorkersâ€™ compensation statutes are to be construed in favor of coverage. . . .â€Â  Lester v. S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp. Commâ€™n, 334 S.C. 557, 561, 514 S.E.2d 751, 752 (1999). Â Any reasonable doubts as to construction should be resolved in favor of coverage.Â  Id. at 561, 514 S.E.2d at 753. 
Section 42-9-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) provides the schedule for compensation for various injuries under this stateâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation system.Â  Subsection (14) provides that for the loss of a foot a worker is to receive 66 2/3% of the average weekly wages during 140 weeks.Â  Subsection (15) provides that the compensation for the loss of a leg is 66 2/3% of the average weekly wages during 195 weeks.Â  In cases involving partial schedule member losses, the amount of the award is proportionate to the percentage of loss of use of the member.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (18) (1976).
Henry Company cites Dunmore v. Brooks Veneer Co., 248 S.C. 326, 149 S.E.2d 766 (1966), for the proposition that an injury to the lower extremity below the knee not causing damage to the knee, thigh, or hip joint is considered an injury to the foot and not the leg.Â  In Dunmore, the workerâ€™s foot was crushed, necessitating amputation.Â  Id. at 331, 149 S.E.2d at 768.Â  His physician determined that the optimum site to make the amputation was approximately five to seven inches below the knee.Â  The reason for this was that a stump of that length would heal more quickly and provide sufficient leverage for walking.Â  Such procedures are called â€œsite of electionâ€ amputations.Â  Id.Â  The court held that since a portion of the leg was amputated to assist the worker in accommodating for the loss of the foot, the injury would be considered a total loss of the foot only, and not a total or partial loss of the leg.Â  Id. at 331-33, 149 S.E.2d at 768-69.Â  
However, this case neither involves a site of election amputation nor a total loss of a body part.[1]Â  The injury in the present case, rather, is similar to the injury in Durant v. Ancor Corp., 209 S.C. 509, 41 S.E.2d 96 (1947).Â  In Durant, the worker was injured when acid splashed on his right leg just above the ankle.Â  The commissioner awarded the worker compensation for seventy-five percent loss of use of his right leg.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court reversed, finding the only reasonable inference from the testimony is that the worker suffered, at most, a disability of the foot and not the leg.Â  The court noted that the worker testified that his â€œleg pained him and was stiff in the morning,â€ but discounted this testimony in light of his testimony as a whole that his loss of use was in his ankle joint or instep.Â  Id. at 510-11, 41 S.E.2d at 96.
In the present case, contrary to the evidence presented in Durant, there is ample testimony that Peoples suffered a disability to his leg, not just his foot.Â Â Â  Peoples testified that during a typical workday, â€œthere is a lot of pain in [his] leg,â€ and that the pain is â€œnot in [his] foot, itâ€™s in [his] leg.â€Â  Peoples stated that the pain sometimes runs all the way up to the small of his back, but at the time of the hearing, it was confined to his lower leg, â€œright to the back of [his] knee joint.â€Â  The commissioner noted during the hearing that â€œit appears that the right lower leg particularly at the side of the ankle and extending above is about 30 percent larger than the left.â€Â  The commissioner further stated that â€œthere is a scar approximately eight inches in length, approximately a half inch in width that runs from the heel all the way up towards the knee joint and the right lower leg is â€“ from the back, looks significantly more swollen than the â€“ significantly larger and swollen as compared to the left.â€Â  The commissionerâ€™s order found that Peoples walks with a limp, and this is supported by the medical records.Â  The circuit court noted that the Achilles tendon is defined in Taberâ€™s Medical Dictionary as being a part of the leg.Â  
Additionally, while Dr. Davis found Peoples had reached maximum medical improvement on February 2, 2002 and found his permanent impairment rating to be thirty-five percent to the foot, Dr. Seastrunkâ€™s independent medical evaluation found a sixty-two percent impairment rating to Peoplesâ€™ right lower extremity.Â  Peoplesâ€™ own testimony was that he felt he had lost seventy percent of the use of his leg.Â  In fact, the medical records are replete with references to a leg injury.Â  Therefore, we find no error and affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order as to the award for permanent disability to the leg, not just the foot.[2] 
Henry Company next argues that the circuit court erred in finding that Peoples needed Ultracet to control his pain and lessen his disability.Â  We find this issue not properly preserved for appeal. 
The record contains no indication that Henry Company appealed from the single commissionerâ€™s finding that Peoples needed Ultracet to control his pain. At the full commission hearing, Peoples testified that he was taking Ultracet for pain, as prescribed by his physician.Â  This testimony went unchallenged.Â  The full commission concurred with the single commissioner and found that the Ultracet would tend to lessen Peoplesâ€™ disability.Â  When the case was heard before the circuit court, Henry Company did not take issue with the full commissionâ€™s finding that Peoples needed Ultracet to control his pain.[3]Â  The circuit court affirmed this portion of the award.Â  Therefore, we decline to address this argument on appeal.Â  See, e.g., Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 102, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  

  CONCLUSION

  Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is hereby 
  

AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Similarly, the other cases relied upon by Henry Company, Burns v. Joyner, 264 S.C. 207, 213 S.E.2d 734 (1975) and Jewel v. R. B. Pond Co., 198 S.C. 86, 15 S.E.2d 684 (1941), also involve amputation injuries and compensation for the total loss of a body part.Â  Moreover, neither of those cases addressed the question as to whether the claimant was entitled to recover for a loss of foot or loss of leg.Â Â Â  
[2] Courts in other jurisdictions have held that injuries to the ankle involve the leg and not just the foot.Â  See, e.g., Insulated Panel Co. v. Indus. Commâ€™n, 743 N.E.2d 1038, 1043 (Ill. App. Ct. 2001) (â€œ[I]njury to the bones and ligaments of the ankle may be compensable as a percentage loss of the leg.â€); LaBrecque v. Fla. Vocational Rehab. & Div. of Risk Mgmt., 380 So.2d 482, 483 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1980) (stating that an ankle injury could be either a leg injury or a foot injury and the interpretation most favorable to the claimant should be adopted). 
[3] The written briefs submitted to the circuit court by Henry Company do not appear in the record on appeal.Â  Henry Company bears the burden of providing the court with a record sufficient to allow for appellate review.Â  Hundley v. Rite Aid of S.C., Inc., 339 S.C. 285, 306-07, 529 S.E.2d 45, 57 (Ct. App. 2000).Â
